SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) expresses its grave concern at the increasing use being made of sport to advance political causes;
(2) asks all governments and politicians to lay off sports men and women, and to cease to use them as political puppets; and
(3) calls on this Government to use effective diplomacy to ensure that the forthcoming Brisbane Commonwealth Games are not wrecked by senseless boycotts and other forms of political interference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware of the rapidly deteriorating financial situation in Victoria's public hospital system and the fact that by 3 April it will have a deficit of $30m? What steps will the Minister or the Government take to help Victoria to overcome this problem?

—I am not aware of the precise public hospital situation in Victoria because, of course, that is a matter for the State Government to take into account. We are in consultation with the Victorian State Government in relation to finalising the cost sharing agreements which came to an end, as the honourable member would appreciate, last year. Obviously any shortfall which occurs in any State is the responsibility of the particular State government concerned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN AID TO THIRD WORLD COUNTRIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether he has seen a reported statement by Mr Harry Martin, the National Director of Community Aid Abroad, to the effect that Australia's promise of a further $100m in aid to the Third World has turned out to be a sham. Did Mr Martin say that the money would not be spent because of cuts to staffing in the Australian Development Assistance Bureau? What is the position with the expenditure of the overseas aid appropriation in the present Budget?

—I am aware that the National Director of Community Aid Abroad has suggested that Australia's aid program will be underspent to the extent of $100m this year. This suggestion is completely wrong. The so-called freeze on expenditure in respect of aid funds was lifted some time ago and all programs that have been agreed and adequately developed are proceeding. It is anticipated that there will be only a minimal shortfall in aid expenditure this year. If this does occur it will amount to only 2 per cent or 3 per cent of the program. Arrangements have been made for any unspent funds to be carried forward to the 1982-83 aid program without prejudice to the size of that program. Some funds have been transferred from bilateral project aid to bilateral food aid because of the difficulties that were being experienced by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau in having adequate time to assess projects that had been put forward this year. The Government regrets that Mr Martin has misled the public on this very important issue.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that nearly 90 per cent of primary school children in Tasmania and South Australia are covered by the School Dental Scheme but in Victoria only 12 per cent are covered? Will the Minister take action under the program to ensure that in respect of dental health Victorian school children are not penalised by State or Commonwealth government neglect?

—I cannot confirm or deny the statistics that the honourable member put forward. I point out that under the new health funding arrangements brought in by the Federal Government a considerable amount of money has been made available to each of the States. This amount is based upon the actual expenditure last year plus an escalation factor of 10 per cent, which applies also to community health and to the school dental service, to pay for the cost of the continuation of those schemes. I say, because this afternoon two questions have been directed to me concerning the state of the health system in Victoria, that over the years, under the administration of Liberal governments in that State, the Victorian health system has really been quite an example to the rest of Australia. It certainly has not exemplified the wastage which is characterised in the New South Wales health system and which is currently bringing about a situation of quite severe strain in that State.

—I refer the Minister for Science and Technology to reports from a privately sponsored visit to Mawson's Hut and Commonwealth Bay in the Antarctic that indicated rapid deterioration of Mawson's Hut. Because of the rapid deterioration of the hut in its current location, will the Minister, as a matter of urgency, examine the practicability of bringing the hut back to Australia as the basis for an Australian museum?
—I have heard reports of the recent expedition on the state of Mawson' s Hut.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to question No. 4255 on the Notice Paper.
—I uphold the point of order. I call the honourable member for Swan.

—I ask the Minister for Communications: Why has Australia Post banned overtime for its employees in Perth? Is that ban general throughout Australia? What is the current loss per day of Australia Post? How far is it currently in deficit? Is it a fact that Cabinet has deferred consideration of a rise in postal charges? If so, is it to be anticipated that a Cabinet decision on the matter will not be made until after the Victorian State election? Finally, if there is a general ban on overtime for Australia Post will it be lifted during the busy Easter period?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague, the Minister for Industrial Relations, has often told this House of the ills that have befallen the whole Australian community as a result of industrial stoppages and other matters of that ilk. I think the statements made in this place yesterday and the community reaction in New South Wales further demonstrate that in one other area there has been real concern as a result of industrial troubles-in that instance, in the power stations in New South Wales. In Australia Post about $7m was lost as a result of the pre- Christmas industrial action. That amount of money very significantly affected the cash flows of a statutory authority which is charged with the responsibility of covering the costs of the services that it provides throughout Australia. As a result, Australia Post is concerned about its present financial position. It has taken a series of steps to try to contain its outlays and to ensure to the maximum that services to the public are not affected, while the amount of money that it spends in trying to provide the services is no more than is absolutely necessary in relation to the overall high labour cost that affects it.

ANSWER.PARA: I might add that in Australia Post about 80 per cent of the costs of providing mail services in this country are affected by those costs directly related to labour input. As people would know, the combined costs of wage increases and, in some industries, the reduction in working hours have led to about a 20 per cent increase in labour costs in Australia in the last 12 months. To an organisation such as Australia Post, which is very heavily dependent upon labour, obviously that factor is very significant. Australia Post, over the last few weeks, has increased the charges that it is applying to parcels. It is certainly very conscious of the need for it to generate sufficient revenue to provide adequate services to the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister was asked a specific question as to when the cost of postage will rise. He has so far declined to answer that question; therefore his answer is not relevant to the specific question asked.
—The answer being given is relevant.

—As I have indicated, certainly announcements have been made in respect of the parcel charges of Australia Post. Discussions are continuing between the Government and Australia Post with respect to other areas of possible future charge increases. When a decision has been taken in regard to them an announcement will be made.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. I think he would be aware of a very fine adjournment speech which was made last night on the matter of transport. My question is: Does the Minister have power to prohibit smoking in public transport, particularly domestic aircraft? If the Minister has such power, does he intend to exercise it? Is he aware that Scandinavian Airlines System, SAS, has banned all smoking on Swedish air routes? Can he persuade the Australian airline companies to have consideration for the civil rights of the 70 per cent of the population who are non-smokers by prohibiting all smoking in their aircraft?

—There appears to be some doubt as to whether the Commonwealth does have power or authority to ban smoking in aircraft. It does have a power in respect of safety in aviation and that power, of course, has been exercised. I have asked my Department to seek further legal advice in respect of this matter because of the number of representations I have had from non-smokers or from people who are offended by the smoking of other people while travelling on aircraft. I do consider that operators should reflect community attitudes and expectations in this regard. I am advised that the airlines continue to monitor the demand for seats for smokers and non-smokers and remain sensitive to any alteration to the demand. Indeed, I wrote to both airlines, Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans Australia Airlines, suggesting that they might review the number of seats for non-smokers available to people seeking such seats as soon as possible. I think it is very important for the airlines to show sympathetic consideration for the travelling public, of whom I think 70 per cent are non- smokers. I am not aware of Scandinavian Airlines having exercised a power to ban smoking on its aircraft. I will, however, investigate that report.

—Is the Minister for Science and Technology aware of the serious threat to Australian eucalypt forests from the condition known as the die-back syndrome ? Is he aware that the problem is especially serious in the electorate of the right honourable member for New England? Can the Minister indicate whether there is a co-ordinated research program into the die-back syndrome between the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and State authorities? If not, will the Minister take action to initiate such a research program in order to come to grips with this serious national problem?

—I am aware of the serious problem of die-back in New England. The problem exists in other parts of Australia as well. There are various causes. I understand that one of the causes suggested for it in New England is the fact that the forests have been cleared and there are a lot of isolated patches of trees which are attacked by insects, particularly the Christmas beetle. I understand that New South Wales is undertaking a good deal of research into this matter, assisted by the CSIRO. I am not sure how much co-ordination there is. I will check and let the honourable member know the result.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourchier Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Industry and Commerce advise what action he has taken to assist the Bendigo Ordnance Factory to participate--

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask honourable members to be patient. They will hear the good news in a moment.

—I will start again. Will the Minister advise what action he has taken to assist the Bendigo Ordnance Factory to participate in the recent contract awarded to the Demag organisation? This contract is to supply two dredges for the State Electricity Commission of Victoria.

The Factory does have the capability to manufacture parts and sub- assemblies for the two dredges. —I ask a question of the Prime Minister. I refer to my questions last week concerning the activities of the Nugan Hand group. The Prime Minister will recall that last week the Minister for Administrative Services said that he knew nothing of departmental reports which showed that an agency of his Government was informed five years ago that Frank Nugan and Michael Hand were 'bigger than anything you have ever seen here in the heroin game and are said to be part of an American security organisation'. Is the Prime Minister concerned that apparently no action was taken by his Government on this information? Has the Prime Minister consulted his colleague, the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs and now Minister for Education, as to whether he knew of these reports at any time during his period of ministerial responsibility for the Australian Narcotics Bureau? Is the Prime Minister aware that this information concerning Nugan and Hand was given to the Bureau in May 1977, just two months before anti-drug campaigner Mr Donald Mackay, of Griffith, disappeared? Is he also aware that six months later, in November 1977, information was passed on to the Bureau alleging Nugan Hand's connections with identified United States security personnel and Nugan's involvement in the smuggling of money out of the Griffith area hidden in wine casks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: — There is a joint task force established between the New South Wales police force and the Commonwealth police force and there has been very close co-operation between the two governments and the two police forces. In addition, there is the royal commission into related matters. The first report of the task force is available. I have offered to make a copy of that report available to the honourable gentleman if he wishes to have it and an officer of the department, if it has not already given the honourable gentleman a copy, will be waiting upon him to give him a copy for his perusal after Question Time.

ANSWER.PARA: The task force itself recommended that the report not be published because of pending matters. That is plain from the statement that I tabled, which was in fact drafted by the task force. The same reasons were referrred to in a letter from an officer of the New South Wales Premier's Department to me. A copy of that letter will also be made available to the Leader of the Opposition. I mention these matters because this Government was responsible for approaching the New South Wales Government to see that the terms of the task force were widened to make sure that it would be able to look at matters that might offend Commonwealth law as well as State law. That was done on our initiative and the letters in relation to that, Mr Wran's response and Mr Anthony's further response, have been tabled in the Parliament. Therefore, the examinations that are under way by the task force are very much a result of initiatives of this Government.

Against that background, I have no intention of going into the details of papers on things that might have occurred some time ago, because if the honourable gentleman believes that there are certain matters that need examination he is fully at liberty to bring those matters to the attention of the task force, which is composed of police from the State of New South Wales and the Commonwealth, or, if he prefers, to the royal commission. He would be able to make the papers available to those bodies. If there is anyone speaking to him who he believes has evidence that has not properly been brought before the police task force and/or the royal commission, that person should be persuaded to go forward and give that evidence. If there is a question of protection being needed, protection would be given if necessary by both police forces to that person. But if the honourable gentleman continues just to try to dribble out in this Parliament for political purposes matters that are alleged to be secret, concerning several years ago, then so be it. He will do himself no credit because governments have established the appropriate means for examination of these matters, through either the royal commission or the joint police task force.

One of the reasons-this, again, should have been plain from the statement that was tabled-why the first report of the first task force is not to be published is that it would prejudice certain matters that could or should lead to prosecution. That obviously means that the police task force has real teeth and is getting about its business in a proper way. If the Leader of the Opposition wishes to enhance the cause of justice in Australia, he will make whatever evidence he has available to the task force and/or the royal commission and persuade anyone who might be feeding him with bits and pieces to do the very same thing. We have established the means of examining these matters. This Government took the initiative in widening the terms of reference so that no matters could be excluded. The Leader of the Opposition has no justification whatsoever for keeping information that he might believe to be relevant private to himself.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TACTICAL FIGHTER PROJECT: AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY PARTICIPATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Defence, concerns the purchase by Australia of 75 F18A fighter aircraft. Has the Government settled what benefits Australian industry will get from the tactical fighter replacement project? At this time I would be particularly interested in any benefits that might flow to Victorian industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The occasional cynic in our midst may draw the conclusion that there is an election on in Victoria. I know that my honourable friend is not motivated by such a consideration. The honourable gentleman has taken a long and very sustained interest in this project.
—Do you think he knows something about it?

—I could not congratulate the honourable member for Port Adelaide on that score. I find the honourable member for Port Adelaide companionable and genial but at times so rough that I feel sorry for every sheep he ever shore!

ANSWER.PARA: This is a very large and very expensive project and the total cost in August 1981 prices is of the order of $2,430m. No other government-I take a quiet pride in this-has ever sought to ensure an Australian industry participation of the proportion that obtains on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are their anticipations now?

—I am delighted that my cultural adviser has offered his assistance. We have already determined some $530m or $540m of contracts regarding the F18A project-that is, in direct Australian industry participation. Our search and our anxiety continue. I would like to say to my honourable friend that Victoria, by dint of circumstances and, to use an in-word of yesterday, 'historical' experience, is peculiarly well fitted to discharge this burden. I thank my honourable friend for his interest over the years. I can assure him and those who join with him in Victoria that this interest will be sustained.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications. As a gesture of humanitarianism, will the Government follow the example of West Germany and allow food parcels to be sent free of charge to Poland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman may not be aware, as he comes from that rather antiquarian institution where I know the rights of back benchers are not protected, that federally we have done a great deal to assist Poland. A great deal of money has been contributed directly by the Commonwealth-I think it is of the order of $1 million-and the provision of assistance that has been directed from the Federal Government has been specifically intended to try to assist those people who have been in such a grievous plight. However, it has not been a Federal practice for individual institutions of the Commonwealth specifically to provide aid in the form of concessional assistance for posts or things of that sort.

ANSWER.PARA: On the other hand, my colleague the Treasurer, as honourable members may know, has announced in this House tax deductibility for contributions to the several appeals to provide funds for Poland. I suggest to the honourable gentleman that, if he has in his electorate constituents who wish to provide help, they will find that the Commonwealth Government has provided a range of very positive measures, all of which are in specific recognition of the grievous plight of the citizens of a country for which I think we all share a common concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications in his capacity as representative of the Minister for National Development and Energy. Is the Minister aware of the serious concern of the people of northern Victoria, the Riverina of New South Wales and the Riverland area of South Australia over the excessive use by the New South Wales Government of Snowy water for hydro- electric power generation? What safeguards exist to prevent power generation for New South Wales this winter causing a dangerous reduction in the level of Snowy water storages which would endanger water supplies for towns, irrigation and salinity control along the Murrumbidgee and Murray rivers in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the operation of the scheme is controlled by the Snowy Mountains Council, a body to which the Commonwealth Government, the Government of New South Wales and the Government of Victoria are signatories. In general, the scheme is designed to ensure the maximum use of the water resources of the Snowy, taking into account the two principal areas to which the water is directed, one being the irrigation scheme and the other the provision of water for electricity generation. The amount of water released from the Snowy scheme to alleviate the present electricity shortage in New South Wales, I am told, has been well within the amount agreed by the Snowy Mountains Council as late as December 1981. Some 300 gigalitres of additional water have been made available for electricity generation during the operating year to 30 April 1982, as a result of fairly heavy snowfalls last winter, but the balance, another 300 gigalitres, is being provided on an overdraw basis subject to specific conditions, including payback in the following year to minimise any potential future loss of water to irrigation purposes.

ANSWER.PARA: I am told that the scheme is being operated within its design capabilities but that its main storages are at present, regrettably, only 45 per cent full. The concern must be to try to balance the two committed end uses of the water to ensure that there is no prejudice to either the water supplies on the Murray and the Murrumbidgee river systems, on the one hand, or electricity generation, on the other hand. I shall draw the attention of the Council to the honourable gentleman's question, but I assure him that, as far as the Federal Government is concerned, while it will do all that it can to assist those who are so hard pressed as a result of the industrial irresponsibility of the New South Wales Government, it accepts its continuing responsibility to water consumers on the Murray and Murrumbidgee river systems.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker. I require the Minister, under Standing Order 321, to table the documents he has read, or, if he prefers, to have them incorporated.
—I read it all. I will table the document.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I draw his attention to an article in the Bulletin of today's date at page 100, called 'The Robots are on the March', described as being by one Phillip Lynch, who is described, with an asterisk, as Minister for Industry and Commerce, which advocates that Australian factories should adopt robotisation as soon as possible. Does this article represent a considered Government view, or is it the Minister's personal opinion? Has he discussed the issue with the Prime Minister and other related ministerial colleagues, particularly the Minister for Industrial Relations? In view of Australia's unemployment now standing at 7 per cent, does he agree that this is a singularly inappropriate time for a senior Minister to be advocating robotisation? Finally, does this represent a fourth example of the Minister expressing a personal view, following his recent highly publicised and controversial statements on pensions, public sector spending and company tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is absolute rubbish. If the honourable gentleman knew anything about the needs of Australian manufacturing industry at present, he would know full well that it needs to continue developing its competitive edge, and that that requires that industry should use the latest technology available, whether here or overseas, and that technology should certainly include the application of industrial robots at present. I should have thought that the honourable gentleman, with his understanding of science and technology disciplines, on which he has spent some considerable time, would know that robots are one of a number of computer-based manufacturing techniques which are achieving increased application world wide. As the honourable gentleman should know full well, they are achieving increasing acceptance within Australia. I say here in clear terms that, whilst the understandable concerns of employees must be considered, there is no option but for those sections of industry which have a capacity to robotise to in fact do so because it is the development of the competitive edge of Australian manufacturing industry that will help, as I hope the honourable gentleman both understands and acccepts, to build job security within Australia.
—Australia?

—The honourable member's xenophobic attitudes on these issues are well known. The fact is that, if industry in this country does not employ those advanced technological techniques which are now available to industry in other countries, of course we will lose the competitive edge and as a direct consequence of that the job security provided by those companies and those firms will be threatened. That is the serious point that I put to the honourable gentleman. Technology, in the view of this Government, builds jobs. I recognise that there is understandable concern at times on the part of the work force but unless we become more competitive we will not be able to continue to employ those Australians seeking jobs at present. That, of course, remains a cardinal and significant objective of this Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to the plight of certain members of religious minorities in Iran, particularly those of the Bahai faith, who are frightened to return to their homeland. Is the Government able to make special provision for such people to settle in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last August, on a motion of the honourable member for Mackellar, the House expressed its concern about the situation of Baha'is in Iran. I am pleased to say that since the introduction of our special humanitarian program it is now possible for Baha'is who get out of Iran to be processed and accepted in Australia. Of course there are obvious difficulties in reaching people who are actually in Iran but quite a number now in neighbouring countries are being processed. Many have been accepted. We are doing all that we can to assist them in their plight.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, the migration procedures are available to Baha'is elsewhere in the world and many of those are receiving support from the community in Australia. As well as that, I know the Foreign Minister has certain initiatives in mind. We are actually participating through the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to do what we can to alleviate what is a very grave situation. They are settling very effectively thanks to a wide community support structure here and I can assure the House that it is one of the priority areas so far as our special humanitarian program is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce will recall his declaring last night on the radio program PM that, before he made his well publicised statement about the need to reintroduce asset means tests on the modest savings of pensioners a few weeks ago, he cleared that statement with the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney. Before he made the statement on Monday that there should be a reduction in corporate taxes for business, presumably especially for big business, did he clear that statement with the Treasurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no need to do that. I welcome the opportunity to comment on a matter which was raised on both sides of the House yesterday because I think the facts of the issue ought to be very clear to both sides of the House. The Government very shortly will be considering the Industries Assistance Commission report on budgetary assistance for industry and that will require the Government to look at the question of corporate taxation which clearly comprehends both sides of the Government's balance sheet. We take from companies by way of company tax and at the same time companies, Australian industry and commerce generally are the recipients of major areas of government support. All that statement at the Bureau of Industry Economics conference represented was a clear indication that those matters will be before the Government when we look at that IAC report. I invite the honourable gentleman, who I think will look at the plain words which have been used, to look at that speech and to make the same judgment.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a matter which has been on the public record for some considerable period. We announced the IAC reference some months ago. We said then that in a normal management sense it was the compelling objective of this Government to say to industry, through its capacity to respond to the normal inquiries of the IAC, what would be the most cost effective program of assistance which we could provide to industry given its particular needs at this time. It is simply a question of priorities and those priorities will be before the Government. Therefore, for me to assert that these issues to which the Government would need to give close consideration was in fact to recall the statement which was originally made and which in quite clear terms set out the Government's need to be informed by industry on the recommendation by the IAC as to what those priorities in fact ought to be.

The honourable gentleman should be the last man in this House to talk about support for industry or the corporate sector. He knows that the policy of the Australian Labor Party, more radical now than it was when it was in government, would seek to withdraw the investment allowance and at a critical time in the history of this country, given the economic circumstances, the honourable gentleman would seek to put further pressure on wages and would apparently give support to a reduction in the working week. I am yet to hear the honourable gentleman say anything about those strikes which have created such havoc in Australian industry and which are creating havoc in New South Wales at present. These are the issues to which the Leader of the Opposition ought to give consideration.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TASMANIA: REDUCTION IN SHARE OF TAX REVENUE

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Treasurer aware that the Tasmanian Minister for Education, Mr Aulich, has claimed that Commonwealth grants to Tasmania will be reduced by $64m and therefore there will need to be severe cutbacks in education spending? As Mr Aulich has convened meetings with school principals to discuss emergency plans, can the Treasurer confirm whether there is any validity in Mr Aulich's claim?

—I am aware of that claim. The honourable gentleman's colleague, the honourable member for Braddon, asked me a similar question last week. It was such a good question and such a good answer that I am very pleased to be asked the question again. I will be happy to repeat the answer. I can assure the honourable member that there is absolutely no truth at all in the claim made by the Tasmanian Minister for Education. To make such a claim is to mislead completely the people of Tasmania and to misrepresent completely the level of Commonwealth support for the State of Tasmania during the period of office of the Fraser Government. I can only say that the remarks of the Tasmanian Minister for Education are typical of the desperate remarks of Ministers in a government which is about to be booted out of office.

—Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, I want to table some documents. Last week the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) challenged me to table certain documents to which I had made reference in the course of Question Time and debate in the Parliament. Today the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) suggested that the documents should be made available. I have deleted relevant names in a way which I believe removes any opportunity to identify particular people. Accordingly, I seek leave to table three relevant documents.
—Is leave granted?

—Mr Speaker, may I ask the Leader of the Opposition whether, if he is given permission to table these documents, he will make the documents available in full to the joint police task force, with the names included, and also give the names of the people who are giving information to him so that if they need protection they can be given protection and so that the true course of justice can be fulfilled by giving to the police task force total access to any material that might have any relevance whatsoever to these matters?

—The Prime Minister has been asked whether leave is granted. I interpret what the right honourable gentleman said to mean that leave will be granted if the conditions are met. Will the conditions be met?
—I do not think that the Prime Minister can impose those conditions, which are extraterritorial to Parliament.
—Is leave granted?

—Mr Speaker, I said that before we would give leave we would want to know whether the Leader of the Opposition will co-operate with the police task force. That is a plain question. He owes it not only to this Parliament but also to the whole community of Australia, which is vastly concerned about these investigations. Let the Leader of the Opposition co- operate with the forces that are there to preserve justice and to seek out the truth. Will he co-operate or will he not?

—The Leader of the Opposition has asked for leave to table documents. I must put to the House the question: Is leave granted? If there is a single dissentient voice, leave is not granted, as the Leader of the Opposition knows. As a matter of indulgence, I allowed the issues to come out so that the attitudes could be exposed, but I think I am now obliged under the Standing Orders to put the simple question: Is leave granted?

—Mr Speaker, before you put that question may I quote from Mr Justice Woodward's report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, Volume 3 at page 1650, which is relevant to this issue of the competence and the extent of the authority to investigate the matters that the Prime Minister is talking about.
—Order! The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—Clearly, Mr Justice Woodward does not believe that it has the authority.

—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. There are other means by which the honourable gentleman can speak but, under the present circumstances , it is a simple issue of whether leave is granted.
—The Government would be prepared to grant indulgence to the Leader of the Opposition to answer the Prime Minister's question. If not, the answer is no.
—Leave is not granted. I call the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment concerning the presentation of papers.
—I do not know what they are hiding.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order, I understand that the Leader of the Opposition is now indicating willingness to pass the documents to the police .
—I said I do not know what you are frightened of. What are you hiding? Why won't you accept the documents?
—Are you prepared to pass the documents to the police?

—The Leader of the House will resume his seat. The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. I have disposed of this question. If a subsequent application for leave to table is made, I will put it to the House. There is at present no application before me. DEBATE.TITLE: OECD MANPOWER AND SOCIAL AFFAIRS COMMITTEE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr N.A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-Mr Speaker, I wish to make a statement to the House on the meeting of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Employment Ministers in Paris on 4 and 5 March 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: This meeting was held at a time of growing concern in OECD member countries about the problem of unemployment. Estimates prepared by the OECD Secretariat indicate that the level of unemployment in the OECD area as a whole will reach 28.5 million by the end of 1982, which represents 8 per cent of the labour force , and will remain at that level until at least the middle of 1983.

Honourable members may have noticed the news report today that, according to statistics just issued by Eurostat, the European Economic Community statistical agency, unemployment in the European Community shows 'an upward tendency' and that the underlying trend of the figures was for a worsening labour picture. It was not, then, surprising that the OECD meeting saw an active debate on the causes of unemployment and proposals to cure it. The impact of unemployment on disadvantaged groups in the labour market, particularly youth, was a special matter of debate.

Naturally, differing opinions were expressed during the meeting. Each country had the opportunity to elaborate its position, to seek reactions to that position, and to question other members on their labour market policies. This process of free discussion resulted in a very effective exchange of views. More importantly, it facilitated the development of a consensus among member countries on some key employment issues facing the OECD area.

It should be noted that there is not universal agreement amongst all OECD member countries on all matters relating to employment. This is apparent from the communique issued after the meeting where, on certain issues, reference is made to the views of 'some ministers' or 'a number of ministers'. However, there is agreement on the basic economic issues and this is equally apparent from the communique.
The communique is therefore a significant document and I commend it to the attention of honourable members. I ask leave to incorporate the communique in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The communique read as follows-
ORGANISATION FOR ECONOMIC CO-OPERATION AND DEVELOPMENT
Press/A(82)12 Paris, 5th March 1982
MEETING OF THE OECDMANPOWER AND SOCIAL AFFAIRS COMMITTEEAT MINISTERIAL LEVEL4th- 5th March 1982
COMMUNIQUE

1. The Manpower and Social Affairs Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development met at Ministerial Level on 4th and 5th March 1982 under the Chairmanship of Mr Johannes Marten den Uyl,-Minister for Social Affairs and Employment and Deputy Prime-Minister for the Netherlands. Vice- Chairmen of the meeting were M. Jean Auroux, Ministre du Travail for France; the Honourable N.A. Brown, Q.C., M.P., Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs for Australia; the Honorable Raymond J. Donovan, Secretary of Labor for the United States; and Mr Ingemar Eliasson, Minister of Labour and Energy Affairs for Sweden.
I-GENERAL CONDITIONS FOR INCREASING EMPLOYMENT

2. Ministers recognised that the process of recovery from the economic difficulties of the 1970s had been slow and is likely to be protracted in many countries. Unemployment in the OECD area as a whole is forecast to reach 28 1/2 million by the end of 1982, corresponding to 8 per cent of the total labour force, and to remain at that level until at least mid-1983. It is recognised that the extent and persistence of unemployment varies from one country to another.

3. Ministers expressed their deep concern about the human and social implications of the extremely grave economic and social problems induced by such high levels of unemployment. They expressed their firm determination to combat unemployment in the short and medium term and to contribute to speeding up the creation of jobs in various sectors of the economy, as well as a more even distribution of jobs among the working population. They underlined that such efforts could only be pursued with success in the framework of a concomitant and effective combat against inflation, as well as in the context of active international co-operation and open trading relationships, bearing in mind the conclusions of the OECD Council at Ministerial level.

4. In seeking solutions to these problems, Ministers recognised that employment is affected both by factors common to all Member countries and by features special to individual countries. For all countries a better employment performance will inevitably be conditioned by a better economic performance, involving a wide range of macro-economic and labour market policies.

5. Ministers expressed their concern about high interest rates, but recognised the need to continue to fight against inflation, and to keep industrial costs in check, so as to contribute to the expansion of employment. In that context they noted the desirability for the parties to collective bargaining in many countries to take into account constraints on the growth of real incomes under present economic conditions, bearing in mind the need for maintaining an equitable distribution of income. This together with appropriate action to contain non-wage labour costs and social benefits, would foster productive investments. It will also enable governments, where appropriate, more readily to take measures to accelerate the pace of economic recovery.

6. Having regard to both the challenge and potential of technological progress Ministers stressed the need for the creation of sufficient new jobs to absorb the growing labour force and reduce present levels of unemployment. They regarded the encouragement of investment as an essential basis for employment growth.

7. Ministers emphasized that labour market policies are an important form of investment, notably those which improve the quality of human capital, productivity and mobility of the labour force. There was a clear need for such labour market policies to augment the productive potential of the OECD economies and thereby to promote non-inflationary growth. Quite as important as the question of more resources is the reallocation and effective management of existing resources, given constraints on the growth of public expenditure. Ministers also emphasized that expenditure cuts should not undermine those social programmes which they deemed essential for social solidarity in difficult times.

8. Ministers agreed that the success of policies to combat unemployment would depend, to a considerable extent, on active co-operation by working people and employers. Realism about trade-offs between wages, social benefits and employment-creating investment is necessary if a sustained recovery leading to higher levels of employment is to be achieved. They therefore welcomed the frank and positive discussions which took place in the consultations with trade unions (Trade Union Advisory Committee) and employers (Business and Industry Advisory Committee) prior to the meeting, and agreed that it was important in the present economic and social situation to promote a climate of co-operation between governments, employers' organisations and trade unions, both nationally and internationally; to improve the quality of information exchanged between the parties; and in other ways to help to create the conditions for an effective social dialogue within firms and in society at large.
II-THE ROLE OF LABOUR MARKET AND SOCIAL POLICIES

9. Bearing in mind the above fundamental conditions and constraints, Ministers agreed that employment, manpower and social policies had an important role to play, in the short as well as medium term, in efforts to achieve:
sustained non-inflationary growth as a basis for returning to full employment;
labour market flexibility so as to facilitate positive adjustment to rapid structural change;
a more equitable distribution of employment opportunities;
adequate standards of social protection, whilst ensuring the efficiency and effectiveness of social policies;
a climate of co-operation between working people, employers and governments.

10. Recognising the differences between Member countries in the methods used to solve their problems, they agreed that Member countries should consider and, where appropriate, develop national policies in the following areas, whilst at the same time respecting the need for international co-operation in economic, labour market and social policies.
Assisting a Non-Inflationary Recovery

11. Ministers noted the efforts of several Member countries to introduce a variety of policy measures to fight unemployment, including comprehensive employment plans. They agreed that the emphasis should now, wherever possible, be on measures to underpin a non-inflationary economic recovery by reducing industrial costs and encouraging investment, and particularly on those to create new jobs and assist workers to adapt to new skills, new locations and growing sectors of the economy. The relative merits of specific tax-cuts, selective employment subsidies, incremental investment subsidies and the reform of payroll taxes were discussed. It was recognised that each country would need to design measures to meet its own economic and political circumstances, but also to avoid distortions in both national and international competition. Ministers also agreed that it is now important and timely to reinforce skill training programmes and to develop more flexible and responsive education and training arrangements.

12. Ministers discussed whether the big and growing expenditure on unemployment compensation could in some degree be more productively used to provide jobs and training for the unemployed, without however undermining its role as a safety- net. They recognised, however, that such measures would have in some cases a net cost. They agreed that it was worthwhile to discuss the merits of partly using these funds for training schemes to help the unemployed to get into new jobs; short-time work combined with partial unemployment compensation; temporary public jobs with a strong training element; subsidies for net additions to employment; and financial support for unemployed people who wish to create their own enterprise.
Fostering the Return to More Satisfactory Medium-Term Employment Growth

13. Ministers considered the far-reaching employment implications of new patterns of economic growth resulting from structural change of an economic, technological and social nature. They agreed that it is highly important to ensure that the employment potential of new patterns of economic growth is fully exploited as part of a medium-term policy for returning to full employment. For that reason public authorities should give some priority to the employment effects of policies for which they have a major responsibility such as energy, technology development, transportation, urban renewal and community social services. This could be accomplished either through direct public investment or support to private investment. More generally, taxation and the composition of public expenditure have significant employment effects, and should be taken into account in decisions. In some countries, public authorities are exploring ways and means of stimulating efficient, small-scale business enterprises on a local or regional basis.
The Redistribution of Working Time

14. Large-scale unemployment has raised the question in some countries whether those employed could not work less in order to permit the unemployed to work more. This is not only a question of lower weekly hours, but whole range of possible measures such as early retirement, longer holidays, restrictions on over-time work, shared jobs and part-time work. Ministers underlined that where the redistribution of working time takes place, it should be achieved without increasing production costs, so as to avoid harmful inflationary and employment consequences. Such a non-inflationary approach could be facilitated if workers have a wider range of choices for trading-off leisure against income. A more ambitious objective in some countries could be that, on grounds of solidarity with the unemployed, workers and their representatives would opt for taking substantial parts of achieved productivity gains in the form of leisure and improved working conditions rather than real income. If reductions in working time were implemented they should permit a more flexible use of both capital and labour, thereby improving enterprise efficiency and labour market flexibility.

15. Ministers saw this as a very complex question and some of them expressed caution about the feasibility of worksharing in their countries. Some strongly emphasized that because economic circumstances, productivity growth and technical production requirements vary substantially from sector to sector, any redistribution of working time will need to be developed through collective bargaining and on an industry and enterprise basis. However, a number of Ministers pointed to the need for national policy guidelines so as to avoid inequities between sectors and others to the need for studying the possibilities of internationally co-ordinating such measures.
Promoting a Dynamic, Flexible and Efficient Labour Market

16. Ministers recognised that slow growth had weakened the propensity of workers to change jobs, regions and occupations, and of firms to invest. Despite this, they stressed that it was vital for structural adjustments to changing economic, technological and trade conditions to be actively pursued and they discussed possible impediments to labour market adjustment of some labour market policies. A number of possible measures to support adjustment were considered: more active involvement of workers and employers in the process of change, including profit-sharing in some countries; more extensive and flexible vocational education and training, involving systematic co-operation between education and labour market authorities and the social partners; measures to reinforce labour mobility within and between firms, in balance with policies to foster capital flows into labour-surplus areas, e.g. by establishing enterprise zones, and by improving housing conditions. Ministers recognised the key role of public employment services in providing up-to-date labour market information, counselling and placement services. They also stressed the importance of the employment services in assisting employers to improve personnel practices and in adapting employment and manpower policies and programmes to local conditions in the labour market.

17. Ministers discussed the rapid growth of temporary and precarious jobs which resulted, in part, from high unemployment and growing non-wage labour costs. Some Ministers expressed the view that labour markets sharply segmented between a rigid, highly protected sector and a flexible and insecure sector are socially undesirable and a source of growing inequality. This underlines the need not only to achieve more flexibility in the labour market, but also combat the undesirable aspects of certain employment practices.
Sharing the Burden of Economic Slack

18. Ministers stressed the particular seriousness of youth unemployment and underlined the importance of assisting the proper and equal integration of young men and women into society and the labour market. They recognised the important role to be played by education and training. Ministers discussed the relative merits of private v. public training and the appropriate level of remuneration for trainees. They noted the commitment of some countries to a ''youth guarantee '' whereby unemployed young people are guaranteed an offer of training and work experience as soon as possible after leaving school and becoming unemployed. They also agreed on the need to ensure adequate provision for young adults who are experiencing special difficulties in securing stable employment. Some Ministers stressed the need to encourage more realism in the setting of wage rates for young people. Others underlined the importance of a system combining work and training so as to facilitate the transition of young people into the labour market before they become eligible for adult wages.

19. Ministers also reaffirmed the commitment of their governments to the OECD Declaration of April 1980 on the employment of women which emphasized that governments should ''adopt employment policies which offer men and women equal employment opportunity, independently of the rate of economic growth and conditions in the labour market''. Such policies are particularly necessary in a period of slow growth in those countries where women are disproportionately represented among the unemployed.

20. Ministers felt that due attention should be given to help, according to national circumstances, those groups which are particularly vulnerable to long- term unemployment, notably ethnic minorities, the disabled, older workers including women re-entering the work force. However, Ministers stressed that in order to avoid merely transferring employment problems from one group to another , policies increasing overall employment have to be pursued.

21. Ministers agreed that migration between OECD countries, particularly within Europe, had helped and, in a balanced and equitable form, could continue to assist the promotion of dynamic and flexible labour markets. It was noted that foreign workers and their families should not be allowed to become a reserve of insecure labour simply to compensate for increasing labour market rigidities. They emphasized the importance of economic and social integration measures particularly for women and second-generation youth, and their co-ordination with other manpower and social policies. Taking into account the difficulties of less industrialised Member countries, Ministers emphasized that one of the conditions supporting the voluntary return of migrants is economic development and employment creation in the countries of origin, as well as maintaining the cultural and linguistic identity of their children. Ministers agreed that continued co-operation between the Member countries concerned would help to assure a better concertation of policies on migratory movements.
Improving the Interaction between Social Policy, the Economy and Labour Markets

22. Sluggish econonic growth has placed an increasing burden on the provision of social services and benefits, in particular unemployment benefits, and at the same time constrained the resources to finance expenditure on social welfare. These developments have led to the political debate about whether the continued growth of social benefits can be afforded, whether social policies are efficient in achieving their goals, and whether desirable market incentives to save, invest and work are being helped or hindered by the side effects of social policies. Ministers agreed that there was a common will to recognise the human costs of economic and social change, and to ease the financial and personal burdens on individuals. Social and labour market programmes were even more necessary under conditions of low growth and rapid structural change. It was also recognised by some countries that there was a need for redrawing of priorities, for efficient management and for adequate level of social benefit. This was not only a matter of national solidarity, but also of decentralisation in some countries where feasible, so as to harness the energy and imagination of local communities.

23. Recognising the need to achieve a balance between equity and efficiency, Ministers discussed the unintended labour market effects of a variety of social measures, reaching the conclusion that there is no definite evidence as to the nature and size of distortions. However, reforms are desirable and being made in some of these measures, in accordance with national conditions and needs, so as to sharpen their effectiveness. Some countries relying heavily on payroll taxes for financing social security, are considering modifications to alleviate the cost to enterprises. Some Ministers noted that job security and minimum wage provisions, while designed to protect the majority of workers, can act to exclude weak groups, like youth and women, from employment, expecially when there are insufficient employment opportunities. They also felt that while the level and duration of benefits for the unemployed should be adequate, they should encourage, not inhibit, the search for and acceptance of available and suitable jobs.
Strengthening Consultation and Dialogue between Workers, Employers and Governments

24. While the methods and content of consultation and dialogue would differ between countries, Ministers agreed that it could help to create the conditions for a resumption of non-inflationary employment growth nationally and in the OECD area as a whole. It was agreed that consultation and dialogue could include a wide range of topics including many of those discussed above.
III-FURTHER WORK OF THE MANPOWER AND SOCIAL AFFAIRS COMMITTEE

25. During the meeting it was suggested that the future work of the Manpower and Social Affairs Committee should reflect not only the areas of work and priorities which emerged at the meeting, but also, within the framework of the Programme of Work and Budget of the Organisation, the following issues;
(i) measures to promote the access of women to the labour force;
(ii) the effectiveness and efficiency of selective labour market interventions;
(iii) a possible action programme on local initiatives for employment generation;
(iv) a review of current and medium term employment problems and policies in the OECD Member countries;
(v) Member countries' experiences and further policy options for dealing with youth labour market problems;
(vi) a study of the methods of shortening working time and its economic and social implications.
26. Under the present conditions, the Committee considers that it would be desirable to hold another meeting within two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I turn now to consider the three main issues referred to in the communique. These are: The economic context for employment growth; the position of youth in the labour market; and the capacity of education and training systems to meet manpower requirements.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The discussion by Employment Ministers of the conditions for employment growth inevitably moved into the wider area of economic policy. The priority to be given to the control of inflation at a time of high and rising levels of unemployment was closely examined.

This discussion is significant in the light of the policies being pursued by the Australian Government. The communique records the view of OECD Ministers that efforts to combat unemployment can only be pursued successfully in the framework of an effective anti-inflationary policy. Active international co- operation and open trading relations were also identified as other fundamental conditions for success in defeating unemployment.

The control of inflation is fundamental to the economic policies of this Government. OECD Ministers have confirmed that that is the only way to defeat unemployment. Australia is on the right track in creating the conditions for a reduction in unemployment. It is the only way of defeating unemployment and we will not defeat it until all sections of the community come to accept this basic fact. Substantially, this means that we must keep control over our wage costs. Both the direct cost of wages and salaries and the costs that come from shorter working hours and industrial disputes. There should now be no doubt in anyone's mind that if wage costs escalate and do so too quickly, employment will suffer. There should be no doubt in anyone's mind that we have seen in Australia exactly that situation. We have seen successive wage increases, both in direct wages and salaries and in the cost of shorter working hours and the cost of industrial disputes. We have seen all of that followed by increased unemployment. We will defeat unemployment when those responsible for it stop pricing workers out of the market.

OECD Ministers have recognised this and expressed their concern. I trust that all sections of the Australian community accept this timely warning and act accordingly. Ministers were quite specific about this. Thus the communique contains the following statement which makes this quite clear:

Ministers expressed their concern about high interest rates, but recognised the need to continue to fight against inflation and to keep industrial costs in check, so as to contribute to the expansion of employment.
I hope that need will be widely recognised in Australia.

Unless wage increases and claims for shorter working hours are restrained and unless industrial disputes are greatly reduced, the outlook for employment in this country will be very bleak. This should concern not only the unemployed but also young people who have yet to enter the labour market, those who have jobs but whose job security cannot now be guaranteed and indeed the whole community. To put it bluntly, unemployment in Australia will probably increase if, as a nation, we continue to price ourselves out of jobs by inflated wage costs, by the increased costs of shorter working hours and by the costs of industrial disputes. There must be restraint and that restraint must be shown by those who make the claims and those who grant them: By trade unions, employers and industrial tribunals.

This is an appropriate time to say that my experience of the OECD meeting, and the associated consultations with the Trade Union Advisory Committee that preceded it, suggest that Australian trade union leaders would do well to strengthen their links with their overseas counterparts, and should participate in OECD-related discussions. it is unfortunate that the Australian trade union movement did not have the benefit of direct participation with employment Ministers at this conference. Australian employers were represented at the pre- conference consultations and by their representative took an active part in proceedings. I believe that Australian trade unions would have a better understanding of the wider issues affecting employment if they were to take part in these consultations and I would urge them to do so in the future.

There appears to be a much greater degree of awareness in the union movement in Europe and the United States of America of the economic consequences of excessive wage increases and other labour costs than there is in Australia. It is little wonder that overseas investors and traders are increasingly looking askance at the behaviour of Australian unions, when considering the prospects of trading with Australia or establishing businesses here. Overseas investors and traders could be excused for thinking that the Australian trade union movement is either ignorant of the economic consequences of its actions or does not care about them.

A final related point that should be made on the economic issues covered by the conference is the recognition by OECD Ministers of the need to recognise investment as an essential basis for employment growth. This view again supports the policy of this Government to encourage investment and by that means generate employment.

The second key area of the ministerial meeting relates to the problems faced by disadvantaged groups in the labour market. This discussion focused particularly on the problems faced by young people, in the context of the OECD secretariat forecast that youth unemployment could reach 17 per cent in the area by 1983. In recognising the seriousness of the youth unemployment problem, Ministers canvassed a number of policy approaches through which young people might be assisted. There was ready acceptance of the important role of education and training, a role which this Government has implemented by the School to Work Transition Program, the Special Youth Employment Training Program and related measures. There was also concern expressed about the level of youth wages, relative to those earned by adults.

Training opportunities for young people was an area of wide discussion. The dual system of training used in Germany, Austria and Switzerland received special attention in the debate and it is probably not insignificant that those countries have low rates of youth unemployment. The dual system combines schooling and on-the-job training and work experience in a wide range of occupations. After the conference I was able to examine the situation at first hand in West Germany. After doing that I consider that the dual system is well worth serious consideration for possible implementation in Australia.

The role of the education system in preparing young people for entering the labour force was an area of discussion which I was particularly pleased to foster. The need to integrate better the efforts of the compulsory education system with post-school training and work experience schemes was fully recognised in discussion. The specific and substantial problems of youth unemployment were therefore recognised at the conference and there was a special commitment to tackle this serious economic and social problem. I hope there is no doubt about the Australian Government's commitment to that cause because it is genuine and unqualified.

This leads me to the third area of the meeting to which I wish to draw honourable members' attention. The maximisation of training opportunities for young people is heavily dependent on the capacity and flexibility of the training system itself. With the rigidities of the Australian apprenticeship system in my mind, I raised the need for reforms in the training system to ensure that training is consistent with the aspirations of young people and the requirements of employers. As the communique indicates, Ministers accepted this theme and agreed that skill training programs should be reinforced; and, that more flexible and responsive education and training arrangements should be developed. This, of course, includes where appropriate the provision of opportunities for training and retraining for adults, as well as for young people.

I hope that this international encouragement to reform is followed through in Australia in co-operation with trade unions, employers and State government authorities who have the principal reponsibility for the apprenticeship laws of this country. The scene for this work has been set by the work which the Commonwealth and States have done over the last 18 months following the report of the Departments of Labour Advisory Committee on prospective demand for and supply of skilled labour 1980-83 with particular reference to major development projects.

Australia has a very real need to modernise our training methods, and to enlarge the range of occupations for which training is available. This will not only provide a better capacity for economic growth but will particularly help the present unemployed and future school leavers to acquire skills and so enhance their job prospects.

I should like to add that it is really no exaggeration to say that the apprenticeship system in Australia today is quite antique and is in need of very substantial reform. Firstly, there is a need for far more scope for adults to undertake apprenticeships. Secondly, there is a need to relate the term of the apprenticeship more directly to the skill being acquired rather than simply slavishly following a fixed term for an apprenticeship. A third area of reform which is one to which my Department has given particular interest and attention is to encourage more female apprentices because the apprenticeship system in Australia is still one that is almost exclusively confined to young men as a vehicle for training.

I hope that with this international encouragement that has come from the OECD Ministers' conference, an encouragement to look for flexibility in training, we can now go forward in a bipartisan way and try to introduce some of these reforms into the apprenticeship system of this country.

The meeting of OECD Employment Ministers was a very valuable one. I am pleased that I had the opportunity to participate in the meeting as Australia's representative. The Government is encouraged by the broad support which the meeting gave to its policies to encourage employment growth and reduce unemployment. Many other matters emerging from the conference should provide material for stimulating debate in Australia. Finally, I place on record the assistance I obtained from our Ambassador to the OECD, Mr Humphreys, and members of his Embassy staff and the assistance of Mr J. Bowdler, First Assistant Secretary to the Department, whose contribution to the conference and particularly to the work of the drafting committee was of very great value indeed. I present the following paper:
OECD Employment Ministers Meeting-Ministerial Statement, 24 March 1982.
