That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is at the outset a point with which I can concur wholeheartedly with the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown), who has just spoken; that is when he said in his speech that the communique from the meeting which he recently attended was a significant document and he commended it to the attention of honourable members. I agree with that statement. But one must say that, whilst the Minister has been a good messenger in bringing back the document, he has been somewhat perverted in his interpretation of what in fact happened at that meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to spend the very brief time that is available to me in looking dispassionately at the communique which came from the meeting rather than, as I say, at the somewhat perverted version which has been given to the House by the Minister. If we look at the document we will find that the Ministers gave a very balanced view of those factors and considerations which should be taken into account if we are to address ourselves to what is, admittedly, one of the very serious problems facing this community and, indeed, facing all other communities in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development area. I refer to the general issue of unemployment and, in particular-the Minister alluded to this and the ministerial meeting gave attention to it-the matter of youth unemployment.

As distinct from the attempt by the Minister to concentrate wholly upon trade unions, excessive wage claims and industrial disputes-they monopolised his statement-if we look at the communique we find, as I said, a very balanced approach to these issues. Therefore, rather than my addressing myself directly to the Minister's statement, it seems much more sensible to turn to the communique. If one does that one finds that the Ministers, after indicating the magnitude of the problem confronting the OECD-28,500,000 people, a figure of enormous magnitude, are expected to be unemployed in the OECD area by the end of 1982-directed themselves to the sorts of things which need to be taken into account in trying to think of solutions to this problem.

At the very beginning of the communique, in paragraph 3, there is reference to the need, within an overall framework of approach to this issue, to think about 'the creation of jobs in various sectors of the economy'. Those are the exact words used. It is a matter of very keen interest to us, on this side of the House, that as we go through the communique, we find in various paragraphs specific reference to the need for governments to look at and to seriously consider undertaking specific job creation programs. We of the Opposition say that because there has been an attempt by the Minister and the Government to pooh-pooh this question of specific job creation programs. I repeat what I have had cause to say before: If the Minister looks at the analyses that were done by his Department in 1977 in regard to the Regional Employment Development scheme that operated in this country he will see that whilst criticisms were made of that scheme, and legitimate criticisms, the analyses suggest that basically the problems were administrative and that when job creation programs are undertaken in the context of an overall macro-economic approach they can, as the experience of a number of European countries has shown, make a positive contribution to this issue.

I plead with the Minister not to close his mind to the positive place that job creation programs can have. I should think his discussions with the Ministers when he was in Paris would have led him to the conclusion that there is a place for them but they should not be looked at as panaceas, as answers by themselves. They should be seen as having the capacity to play a part, within a general macro-economic approach, in reducing the economic and social problems of unemployment. I plead with the Minister not to take some blinkered ideological position on this issue but instead to ascertain from his Department whether in fact there is not in this country, as there has been in other countries of the OECD, a positive place for these programs. As I have said on occasions, the resources of this side of the House are available in a co-operative and constructive way to look at those sorts of issues.

I go from the opening paragraphs of the ministerial communique to look at other issues that are mentioned in the statement. In paragraph 4 of the communique the point is made by the ministerial spokesmen that if one looks at this phenomenon of unemployment in the Western world one will see that there are certain features of it which are common to all the countries concerned and that there are features which, as they say, are special to individual countries. They say:
For all countries a better employment performance will inevitably be conditioned by a better economic performance, involving a wide range of macro- economic and labour market policies.

It is in that sense that I would again plead with the Minister and the Government to understand that it is of no use just bleating as they have done for the best part of seven years and saying: 'Our policy on this issue from Alpha to Omega is to fight inflation. Let us fight inflation. If we beat it, we are going to cure the unemployment problem'. It is simply not enough to utter words like that. It is to be hoped that the experience of the Minister in discussions with these other Ministers in Paris and in informal discussions will have brought home to him that Ministers in other countries understand that concern with inflation is important but if governments are to discharge their obligations to the community it is not enough just to parrot cries about fighting inflation. Governments have to undertake quite specific packages of policies which include labour market policies if they are to address themselves effectively to this question.

Let me nail at the outset the proposition which tends to fall from the lips of the Minister and other spokesmen for the Government that nothing can be done. The experience of certain countries in the OECD area has shown that in fact one can get a much better position in regard to unemployment rates than anything like the average for the OECD or this country. For instance, I would like to compare the unemployment rates in Austria and Sweden with the rates in Australia from 1976 until 1981. In Australia in 1976 the unemployment rate was 4.7 per cent. In Austria it was 1.8 per cent and in Sweden it was 1.6 per cent. In 1977 the unemployment rate in Australia was 5.6 per cent. In Austria it was 1.6 per cent and in Sweden it was 1.8 per cent. In 1978 the unemployment rate in Australia was 6.2 per cent. In Austria it was 2.1 per cent and in Sweden it was 2.2 per cent. In 1979, the rate in Australia was 6.2 per cent; in Austria it was 2.1 per cent; and in Sweden it was 2.1 per cent. In 1980, Australia's rate was 6 per cent; in Austria it was 1.9 per cent; and in Sweden it was 2 per cent. For 1981, the average for the first three quarters for Australia was 5.5 per cent; for Austria, for the first three quarters, it was 2.4 per cent; and for Sweden, for the same period, it was 2.3 per cent. I read those figures to show that it is simply not true to say that, if governments direct themselves in a comprehensive way to the problems associated with unemployment and see that it requires an approach which does not concentrate on inflation alone but includes proper job creation programs as part of an overall labour market policy, in the context of appropriate macro-economic policies, they cannot do something about this problem. Those figures prove that it can be done.

To show the quite partisan nature of the Minister's statement, one only has to turn to that part of his speech in which he talked about the question of costs which arise out of wage increases and the like. He said that Ministers were quite specific about this. He said:
Thus the communiqu'e contains the following statement which makes this quite clear.
He quoted, and this was his quotation:

Ministers expressed their concern about high interest rates but recognised the need to continue to fight against inflation and to keep industrial costs in check so as to contribute to the expansion of employment.

Having quoted that part, the Minister then built his thesis about how the unions alone, virtually, were responsible for inflation and, therefore, for prejudicing employment opportunities. It would have been good if the Minister had had the decency to read the whole of the paragraph. If he had done so, his thesis would have fallen to the ground, because that paragraph, paragraph 5 of the OECD Ministers' communiqu'e, went on. Let me read the rest of the paragraph.
It said:

In that context they noted the desirability for the parties to collective bargaining in many countries to take into account constraints on the growth of real incomes under present economic conditions bearing in mind the need for maintaining an equitable distribution of income. This, together with appropriate action to contain non-wage labour costs and social benefits, would foster productive benefits. It will also enable governments, where appropriate, more readily to take measures to accelerate the pace of economic recovery.

All that we get is the reading out of the impact of wage costs. What the Ministers were concerned to talk about was not simply the impact of wage costs. That has an importance; I am not denying that. But at least they were broadminded enough to take account of the other considerations. However, what does this Government do in terms of the instruments readily available to it to do something about the equitable distribution of income? I remind the House of what the Government does with a very specific instrument of taxation which is available. In terms of fundamental economic analysis, one must understand that, if we are talking about wages and wage increases, for God's sake let us not be myopic about wages and think of them as one-dimensional. To hear members in this House and Ministers of this Government talking, one would think that wages were to be seen only as a cost. Certainly they are a cost, but I have been trying for years to get it into the minds of conservative governments and conservative Ministers that one does not undertake proper economic analysis if one thinks of wages simply in one-dimensional terms. At one and the same time as wages are a cost, the impact of which needs to be taken into account, they are also an income. A wage is at one and same time a cost and an income. If we talk about it just in one-dimensional terms and emphasise the cost element of wages, one has not undertaken one's task properly.

We must remember that, for the great majority of Australians, wages are the only source of income. If the real purchasing power and the real value of wages are allowed to decline, people will not be able to purchase the output of our factories, of our employers, gathered together. The interests of this country are properly to be seen not just in analysing wages as a cost. I am not trying to deny that we must take account of that. But as I said, for God's sake at the same time we must also understand the economic significance not only for employees but also for employers and manufacturers of the importance of maintaining the purchasing power of the people of this community.

There is another way. We do not have to look at wages only in terms of money wages and their relevance to this question of purchasing power. One action which is available to government to affect the real disposable income of people in this country is to see what can be done about taxes, in terms of the wording of this communique, about equitable distribution of income. But this Government has taken the opposite course of equity and of good economic sense by imposing through its period in office an increasing burden, in terms of tax, upon wage and salary earners. I quickly in the brief time I have give the aggregate figures available. Between 1975-76 and 1981-82, total tax receipts will have gone up by 124 per cent. But, within that period, pay-as-you-earn taxation receipts will have jumped by 146 per cent while non pay-as-you-earn tax receipts will have gone up by only 109 per cent. In aggregate terms, that is merely a reflection of the fact that this Government has deliberately, by way of taxation , taken a bigger bite out of wages and salaries and in that way has reduced the equity of the distribution of income in this country.

In the 30 seconds or so I have left I make the point that this communique says that it is very important to maintain the availability of a whole range of statistics which show the overall and geographical position in regard to employment and unemployment. This Government, by abolishing the Commonwealth Employment Service statistics, deliberately took away that instrument from itself. Overall, the document of the ministers is a very valuable document. I believe if people look at it in its totality they will see the pointing of the paths which can be taken in a constructive way with the emphasis the Ministers place upon the need for co-operation within the community. This Government does not foster co-operation; it fosters confrontation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) for his participation in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development conference. It is most significant that Australia be represented at such conferences overseas, particularly when they involve such an important issue as the employment of our peoples. I am sure that the Minister 's contribution to the conference was a most significant one and I am sure we will find not only the communique but also the other information that the Minister would have brought back to Australia to be of increasing value to this country and to the Government in planning various policy propositions in the future that will affect our employment levels. Having said that, I must admit that I was somewhat confused at the contribution just made by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke).
—You would be.

—Yes, I was. I listened with a great deal of interest and I tried to understand it from a layman's point of view. I must admit I was left completely in the dark. The last statement made by the honourable member for Wills was that wages should not just be seen in one dimension, that wages are both a cost and an income. That is very true. If I understood him, he seemed to imply that wages should be seen in the income context as part of the spending power within the community. I can understand the honourable member for Wills putting forward that proposition. During his time with the Australian Council of Trade Unions he consistently put that proposition to the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It struck me at the time he put that proposition on behalf of the ACTU-and even now-that he failed to understand that if the cost element of wages becomes outlandish then there is no income because the person is not working. That, I think, is where the argument of the honourable member for Wills completely comes unstuck. If the cost element becomes so great the employer goes bankrupt, then there is no job; there is no income. That is the end result of the ever escalating impact of wages. We must clearly understand that.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not dispute the statement by the honourable member for Wills that the two- dimensional impact of wages needs to be taken into account. I agree with him on that point. But we must also recognise the capacity of the employer to pay. That consideration must be taken into account because clearly in Australia the majority of employment is provided by what we might loosely call small business, by small employers; not large multinationals. Whilst wages in this country may be fixed to suit the economics of the large corporate factories and companies, that arrangement does not suit the small employer who does not have the same capacity to pay. The only way he can remain in business is by shedding some of his workers. That is where we get to the root of unemployment. I think it is rather fatuous of the honourable member for Wills to say that wage costs do not have an impact on unemployment. Clearly they do. I agree with the claim by the honourable member for Wills that wages are not the only impact on employment. He is quite right in that respect. But in saying that, we should not fatuously dismiss the idea that wages do not have a most significant impact on the unemployment problem in Australia, particularly in the small business area.

One of the other things that the honourable member for Wills claimed-I think this may have been mentioned in the communique from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development conference-was that governments in fact should embark on job creation schemes. The honourable member in his contribution referred to the former Regional Employment Development scheme which was in operation under the Labor Government between 1972 and 1975. The honourable member for Wills quite rightly said that that scheme in fact was discredited during this term, that there were great difficulties with it and therefore it had to be abandoned. I think what also needs to be understood--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented. I did not say it was discredited--
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member may seek to make a personal explanation on that score at a later time. I call the honourable member for Wilmot.
—I am sorry if I impinge on some of the more touchy points that the honourable member for Wills raised.
—At least be accurate about it.

—I do apologise, but this was clearly understood. As I said, I am a layman trying to undertand an academic. I clearly tried to understand the honourable member but I am a layman, not an academic. I freely admit that. We need to understand that if it is suggested that governments should embark on job creation schemes per se what is being said is that governments should raise taxes so that money can be made available to create jobs in some form or other. The fundamental experience of the RED scheme was that in the course of raising taxes to enable governments to create jobs such pressure was put on the private sector, particularly the small business sector, that workers had to be laid off. What we were doing on the one hand was trying to employ people through government job creation schemes and on the other hand putting such pressure on the private sector that for every job created two were lost in the private sector. That is not an advancement; that is going backwards. That was the experience with the RED scheme. So clearly such a scheme does not work in a mixed economy such as exists in Australia. It may work in a socialist economic system where governments control the economy. But we have to remember at all times that roughly 75 per cent of employees in Australia are employed by the private sector and pressure cannot be put on the private sector in order to create jobs in the government sector. If we do that we lose out in the long run because more people will be put off in the private industry sector. That point must be borne in mind at all times.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Wills quite correctly mentioned in his contribution that in Austria the current rate of unemployment is around 2.4 per cent which is very creditable to that country. In January of this year I too was in Austria and was most intrigued as to how that country achieved a rate of 2.4 per cent in unemployment, particularly when it had large numbers of people coming across the borders from communist countries, in particular from Poland. I also inquired of the Government officials I was talking to as to why their rate of unemployment was so low and their rate of productivity so high. Government officials I talked to explained to me that they simply could not remember when they last had a strike. They thought it was somewhere in the early 1950s but they could not remember when the last strike was.

Clearly, the impact of industrial relations in this country is a major influence on the level of unemployment. It puts this country's market potential on international markets at a tremendous disadvantage. It is irresponsible of anyone in this Parliament or outside this Parliament to make a claim that it does not. If the level of industrial disputation in this country could be reduced, it must open up employment opportunities for more people. We should never lose sight of that. A former Treasurer in a Labor government, Mr Frank Crean, clearly recognised-

TALK.START.PARA: —Here comes the record again.

—The honourable member need not worry; I will get to his point. Many of the industrial disputes in this country-this was mentioned in a debate here last week-relate to wage increases in one form or another. But, as Mr Frank Crean correctly identified, one man's wage increase is another man's job. At the moment, many unions are insisting increasingly on higher wage increases and in doing so they are forcing their work-mates out of the work force. Clearly, that is unacceptable. I agree with the honourable member for Wills-this was also mentioned in the Minister's statement-that governments have a very real responsibility to introduce policies that will put more of our people in the productive work force, but we also need to recognise that that responsibility is not just with governments alone. That is unacceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister, in his statement to the House, mentioned a number of things. I was pleased to hear him mention that one of the major policies that this Government has been following since it came to office has been the control of inflation. That is a key element in creating new employment positions and new investment in this country. The honourable member for Wills correctly pointed out that, while the control of inflation is an important element in economic management that will create new investment, it is not the only element. Other economic factors must also be taken into account, wages being a key one. That should never be forgotten. TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly for youth.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Barton has said, particularly those for youth unemployment and for the training of apprentices. A key factor, not only in Australia but also in other OECD countries, is that the training of young people should be kept at a very high level. I am conscious of the fact that this Government has introduced a number of very important and creditable schemes which are working very well to have more and more young people trained in the skilled trades. I was delighted to hear the Minister say not only that the Government is getting involved in trade apprenticeships young people who are leaving the school system and going into the work force for the first time but also that it is retraining other people. There are adults in apprenticeship training who are being retrained in other skills that are in demand or who at a late stage in life have a desire to learn a skilled trade. This is most creditable. It takes account of the shift in the work force and the changes in industry that are constantly occurring. It will ultimately be to the great benefit of this country. Whilst training and other things are important-
—Try a bit of union bashing.
—I do not want to do any union bashing. I am appealing to the unions to be more responsible. That must be a key issue in the creation of new employment.

—I agree with the honourable member that we were in a hell of a mess in 1975 because at that stage we had inherited problems from an earlier government. It concerns me that over the year to January 1982 there was a decrease in teenage employment of 23,200 or 3.3. per cent. This is of most concern and I urge the Government, in looking at employment policies for the future, to give consideration to the factors that impinge upon young people getting into the work force for the first time. —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Innes Mr U.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with the statement of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown), I would like to indicate, firstly , that any resemblance between the major thrust of the communique and the thrust that the Minister has placed on the issue in his statement is purely coincidental. The fact is that, in looking at the economic climate today and considering the very serious issue of unemployment in general, in particular youth unemployment, we have to place responsibility for the economic situation at large at the feet of the Government. Having had all the great programs that we have had since 1975 to transform the social and economic situation in Australia, having gone through the whole process of putting pressure on unions, bashing hell out of them day after day in this place, and having gone through all the restrictive and contractionary Budget strategies that one can imagine, what do we have in March of 1982?

SPEECH.PARA: Inflation is taking off and interest rates in Australia are higher in real terms, as has been pointed out, than those in any of the other countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Unemployment is at the highest level ever recorded. Given the expected rate of economic growth over the next 12 months, we could be looking down the barrel at an unemployment rate in this country of 10 per cent. The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) illustrated quite clearly the way in which, in that context, the communique has been twisted by the Minister in order to mislead people. He will not succeed. The honourable member for Wills gave, to the extent it was possible to do so, a balanced view of the situation in the light of the communique, which I too have read.

The process which ought to be undertaken in order to try to come to grips with unemployment in general and, very importantly, youth unemployment, involves a number of factors. It is no good for the Minister to say that he will follow dogmatically a program of putting his faith in private enterprise in the belief that that will solve the unemployment ills of this country; it will not. In a moment I will demonstrate that the debates which have taken place over a number of years have clearly indicated that other aspects should be considered. For example, a major contribution should be made by the public sector. We have looked at employment growth in the economic context. The Government's programs are worsening the situation. As has been pointed out, any advance upon a growth expectancy of one per cent will be a bonus. If that is to be the case, the unemployment situation will become disastrous.

I turn to the question of the youth labour market. Again, the Minister has talked about school-to-work transition programs and we have been reminded of the expectations of young people under all of the schemes that have come and gone since 1975. Before the Minister snuck out of the country, he put the axe to certain programs, such as the Community Youth Support Scheme which, although they were not the total answer to the problem, were valuable. Nevertheless, they went by the board. The Minister is shaking his head. I point out that the Aboriginal CYSS scheme in any electorate, for instance, and others, have not been replaced. Children-Aboriginals and others-in the most disadvantaged areas of the country, upon leaving school suffer greatly as a consequence of the Minister's actions. He said that such projects would be replaced. They may be replaced in the sweet by and by but a gap will be left that will never be closed . So much for the sincerity of the Minister! Time after time he has carried out the union bashing exercise to which he is prone. He talks about close-knit union protection and unions projecting particular policies-although these, as the honourable member for Wills has outlined, are merely designed to overcome the economic disadvantages which flow from Government policies. At the same time, the Minister is a member of the legal profession, which is one of the most close -knit unions in the country. Before he came into the Parliament his standing in the legal profession would have netted him $300 a day. Yet he stands here blithely running the rule over unions which endeavour to maintain the gap between nominal and real wages. We have here a new Messiah who comes as a messenger boy from the OECD countries, knowing nothing about the industrial background in Australia and proposing that it be handled in a way that would be disastrous for the unemployed. I am sure that there must be other solutions of the problem.

Attention has been drawn to the reference in the communique to the economic cost of wage levels, but it also mentions other ways of obtaining labour market flexibility so as to facilitate a positive adjustment to rapid structural change . If that is to occur, we must have technical education at a higher level and use the resources available to us to cope with those changes. In 1965 the Minister's predecessor, Sir Phillip Lynch-who is now the Minister for Industry and Commerce-when Minister for Labour and National Service convened a meeting in Canberra to study education for work in industry and commerce. A blueprint was laid down. The Minister is shaking his head, but he should look at the blueprint that was laid down for the purpose of issuing a warning about the development of technical training in this country. Unions, employers and the Government agreed upon a blueprint to meet future industry requirements. Nothing has been done about it. The reason we are in diabolical trouble with technical training in this country is once again the fault of this Government, the Minister and his predecessors.

I turn to another matter that is directly related to the matters mentioned in the communique. The Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) referred rather blithely at Question Time to defence expenditure. He talked about offset programs and their being the saving grace of technical training in this country. He mentioned that 30 per cent of the work would be guaranteed to industry. That figure has been cited over the years. In 1980-81 we reached the amazing target of 8.6 per cent. So much for the 30 per cent offset policy! If nothing more dramatic happens in future the opportunity to develop technical training in this country will be once again lost. I put it to the Minister that one of this country's great facilities is the resources that we already have. The defence establishment and other areas of technical training provide a field in which apprentices and other trainees should have been developed over the years.

The Minister has just been to the OECD countries. He has suddenly awakened. He has emerged from the darkness to project a view that has been held generally by anybody who has had anything to do with industrial relations over the last decade or so. He has projected the view that we should have been training people in the areas I have mentioned. I hope that the offset programs will be referred to Australia to undertake, as they should be. I refer not to the construction of concrete blocks for developments in the defence area, but to projects that will enable technicians to be so trained that we will not be at the mercy of overseas producers and people on whom we rely for our defence equipment. If they are not trained under those circumstances, we will lose our offset advantage by default. If we cannot obtain the technicians to carry out the work, we will not be able to do it. That is clearly the situation in some of the major technical areas at the moment. Recently I was present at a hearing at the Wagga Wagga Royal Australian Air Force base which concerned how technical training in the higher areas would be needed for the tactical fighters based in Darwin and the necessary maintenance of the equipment which will go hand in hand with it. The Air Force is madly rushing around trying to train people in those special areas. Unless that program is developed to a higher degree, we will be left to lament once again.

We have heard the hypocrisy about introducing women into the industry. In fact, 300 positions were vacant in the area. In the first year the intake was 110. Thirty positions were vacant, yet not one female was interviewed. Defence Force policy under those circumstances is not to have females in those highly technical areas. That is what we are told. We are also advised: 'Well, maybe the program will improve in the future'. I genuinely hope it will. If we are going to apply those sorts of principles to the development of apprenticeships in general and the inclusion of a range of people who are available, including females, we will have to do a lot better than that.

Another aspect was conveniently ignored by the Minister in what he had to say in once again heaping the blame on the unions. What the honourable member for Wills has said is correct, one cannot be isolated and narrow in one's thinking as to what areas are available for controlling the overall economic situation. Amongst other things, under the heading 'Improving the Interaction between Social Policy, the Economy and Labour Markets', the communique said:
Social and labour market programmes were even more necessary under conditions of low growth and rapid structural change.

It went on to say that there is a need for national solidarity. This Government can get national solidarity only if it is prepared to accept the unions on the same basis as it does the people whom it represents in this place. It is no good criticising organisations for not participating in the program. If the Government is here lambasting them day after day and heaping all the economic ills on their shoulders, then the Government will get the same repercussions from people in that area. If they are going to fall by the wayside economically, by virtue of the policies of the Government, more power to their arm if they are going to go out and fight for it. But there are other ways, if the Government is prepared to participate as a government in securing jobs by creating jobs. In the defence area, what is wrong with opening up the technical training areas for some of the migrant children here instead of going overseas and recruiting tradesmen for the same purpose? Surely there is an advantage in doing that. I am not opposed to bringing migrant tradesmen here but sons and daughters of migrants and Australians are falling by the wayside on the dole market, thrown aside, left to their own devices and ignored by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs while at the same time job opportunities go begging.

I wish the Minister would be more constructive about the communique. From what we have learnt about him, his attitude is par for the course. I hope the Government allows this debate to continue under different circumstances. A general statement ought to be made by the Minister so that all these issues of the training and the participation of the unions can be brought into this chamber. It is not good enough for the Minister to attend the conference like a school boy, run back here on his errand, deliver a communique which he misinterprets and then falsify the situation in this Parliament. Indeed, there needs to be co-operation; the Government will get that co-operation if it takes steps to co-operate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join with other honourable members who spoke this afternoon in saying something concerning the statement made earlier by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown). I commend the Minister for the statement. I believe it is a very comprehensive one and undoubtedly one which sets out the opinions of the Ministers from those Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries who attended the conference. I know that this afternoon certain criticisms and certain favourable remarks must be made within this debate in relation to Australia's economy, the unemployment situation within Australia and all the other factors that we believe concern us here so far as employment is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the interesting thing that the Minister said this afternoon is the fact that the other countries did, in principle, agree with the statement that he made today. In other words, they have expressed concern that there are a possible 17 million unemployed youth within the OECD countries. They acknowledged the fact that the problems we have in Australia are very similar to those being experienced in the other free countries. I do know a little bit about the European scene. I was there in 1979 when Europe generally was short of tradesmen. In fact, tradesmen-carpenters, engineers, plumbers, drainers and others-were receiving more than a teacher received because manufacturing industry, which was supported by the European Economic Community was going ahead . But apparently there has been a change. As we know, a change is taking place in Britain. Over the years Britain has run down. There are certain reasons for this. The problem today is getting those nationalised industries back into free enterprise so that they can expand their wings and employ the young English people. I think we ought to take note of what has happened in Britain.

I was in Japan with a delegation about a month ago. I want to say something about Japan because I believe it reflects upon Australia and the problems that we have. I think everybody knows that after the War Japan formed a new constitution-the constitution of 1946-which was based upon very democratic lines indeed. It is of interest to note that in Japan at present the inflation rate is only 4 per cent, interest rates are 6 per cent and unemployment is 2 per cent. If we ask the Japanese 'Why can you do this in your country and other countries cannot?', the answer they will give is: 'We have small government'. Free enterprise is doing the work. The railroads are practically all owned by free enterprise. Free enterprise is building roads. The government departments are small. They put their work out for people outside government to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is more government intervention in Japan than there is here.

—Even though the honourable member for Wills interjects that there is more government intervention in Japan than here, if he were to ask the Japanese what the effect of automation has been on their country they would reply that it has created more work. I ask honourable members to think of the opportunities that this country of ours has with our natural resources, with the abilities and the attributes that our workers have and with our primary industries. What an opportunity we have to expand our natural resources and our manufacturing industries to feed the world from the great soil that we have. What are we doing about it? I have never been a union basher at any stage of my 15 years or 16 years in the State and Federal Houses and I do not intend to be. I do not in my local Press condemn the unions for what they are doing, but I do appeal to Opposition members who sit here today, including the honourable member for Wills , who was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, to have a little bit of common sense. I appeal to them to have some reasoning as to where this country of ours stands and to accept the tremendous responsibilities we have to our people and to the people of overseas countries, including the Third World countries that the Opposition often talks about. Does the Opposition's sympathy lie with them or with the New South Wales electricity people-the 170-odd-who will not work and who put hundreds of thousands of people out of work in New South Wales at this very moment? None of the Opposition member's will say anything about that. What about the fellow workers of those men? I will not take the matter any further. But the facts are there and cannot be avoided if Australia and the Government is going to look from the practical point of view at what we are going to do to create work and to train young people in this very great country of ours.

SPEECH.PARA: I sound another warning and go back to the Japanese situation once again. Japan is important to us. I believe Japan is our second biggest trader. It is important to our coal industry, our iron ore industry and our beef markets. We should go back and talk to the Japanese. Why, after 1974, did they start to find alternative methods of energy? It was simply because of the price of oil in the Middle East and simply because there was some doubt as to whether they were going to get the supply. So they looked to Australia for coal-steaming coal and coking coal-and iron ore. They looked to Australia for uranium and for liquefied petroleum gas supplies in the future. If the Government were to talk to the Japanese now, who, I know are very courteous, they would say: 'We want a reliable trading partner'. Is Australia reliable? Are we a reliable partner in trade with the Japanese, the Indonesians, the Americans or members of the European Economic Community? Is Australia a reliable trading partner when meat and natural resources cannot be loaded for export and when thousands of people are out of work because they are not permitted to work?

I hope this situation does not continue because the current markets for our natural resources may not be there in the years to come. Technology is such that today the Japanese are looking at building their motor car engines from ceramics . They have almost perfected that technique. They are building car bodies out of strengthened plastic. Last year Japan produced 20 per cent less steel. Let us think about this situation. This is all involved with the report presented by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. He went overseas to consult with other countries. —It is not a matter of replying.
—He asked me a question, Mr Deputy Speaker; am I to be denied the chance to reply?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr N.A. BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. I was simply pointing out that the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Innes) had referred to one of the objectives to be achieved, which was expressed in these words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . labour market flexibility so as to facilitate positive adjustment to rapid structural change . . .
I was endeavouring to make the point that he had omitted to read out these immediately preceding words:
. . . sustained non-inflationary growth as a basis for returning to full employment . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the honourable member for Melbourne still wish to make a personal explanation?

—Yes. The reply of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) still does not satisfy me. The Minister referred to that particular section of the communique. However, I was alluding to the fact that that particular option was amongst a number of other options presented by Ministers of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development for the purpose of an overall look at the problem rather than it being confined to just that area; that, for instance, the reduction of hours or whatever it might be would be only one aspect that ought to be given consideration in the total context of the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I heard today that the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) was going to come into the House and make a statement in regard to unemployment, I was fairly cheerful and I felt that at last the Government had woken up and we would hear some constructive views in regard to unemployment in this country today. All we heard in his statement today was a rehash of the usual diatribe of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) because nine of the 10 long pages of the Minister's speech really related strictly to industrial relations and how the wicked unions and the dreaded workers with their wages push are ruining the country. We hear often from the Minister for Industrial Relations about the big stick which we need to beat the unions with. I honestly thought he would trip into the Parliament after the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs had spoken, second the motion and speak to it. Heaven help us, we were saved from that.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement made today has not one constructive sentence in it. It will not really add to a constructive debate on employment or unemployment, whichever way one wishes to look at it. It is up to the Government and the Minister to lead in that debate. As I have said many times in this Parliament, the range of policies that reflect industrial relations and employment is great. We cannot look at just one area and say we will put X amount of money into a training scheme or whatever and think that that alone will work. As I have mentioned in this place in several speeches, a whole range of policies, including economic policies involving such things as family allowances and interest rates, all affect the monetary situation. Those two things that I specifically just mentioned affect the monetary situation because they do not come into the calculation of consumer price index increases. Because they do not come into the CPI increases, workers are increasingly having to go to their union officials and say: 'Look, we cannot live; we must have more money'. Subsequently there is a wages push, but a justified one when we look at the whole context of the economic policies of the Government. For instance, we have just seen a one per cent rise in interest rates. I am glad that the honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr) raised the point about small business. Of course, buried in that one per cent rise that the Government has just inflicted on us is a one per cent rise in overdrafts, too. Many small businesses are now closing their doors or are about to close their doors because they have been hit yet again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly in Victoria.

—Especially in Victoria. The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) often says that Victoria is a wonderful State. It is a wonderful State. However, he neglects to tell us that it is on a downward slide so fast that it is not funny. I hope that that slide will be eradicated in a few weeks' time. There is a rundown in business. Overdrafts have gone up right across the board, which mainly affects small businesses. This in not good for the whole economic environment in which we now find ourselves. One last point in that regard is that in the last Budget according to the Government's own figures, of course, wages were to rise by 13 1/2 per cent and pay-as-you-earn tax which is paid by the vast majority of workers in this country, was to rise by just on 22 per cent. Many people for their own convenience forget that little aside.

SPEECH.PARA: On page 9 of the Minister's statement he mentioned one word that we have never really heard from this Government before. Let us not forget that a conservative government has been in office for 30 of the last 33 years and the two Labor governments-there was not one Labor government of three years, but two of 18 months-could not really solve all the problems in that time. Let us look at the 30 of the last 33 years. On page 9 the Minister mentions the word 'retraining'. Training and retraining is something that we on this side of the House have been talking about for a long time. It is amazing that the Minister had to travel to Europe, some thousands of miles to the other side of the world, before he could find the word 'retraining'. It is quite incredible. In fact, training and retraining has been going on in Canada for many years. Numerous sources would have told the Minister about that and saved him having to go 20,000 miles to Europe and back. In Canada the Canada Employment and Immigration Commission operates a network of more than 400 Canada employment centres. Canada has numerous programs for training and retraining. The Commission helps employers to train new workers or to retrain existing employees under the Canada Manpower Industrial Training Program. It has such schemes as the Canada Manpower Mobility Program. Such mobility programs include exploratory assistance which allows workers who have no reasonable chance of finding a job locally to travel to another area. Relocation assistance helps workers who must move to another community to find a full time job. Special travel assistance allows workers to take advantage of employment services not available locally. Assistance is given in respect of some of the costs associated with agricultural workers who travel to take seasonal jobs. Trainee assistance is also provided. The scheme provides for employment development programs, creative jobs and search techniques programs. This is all happening in Canada. This scheme did not start in the last year or two; it has been going on for many years. In fact, a very high percentage of people in Canada retrain.

It seems funny that the Minister has had to travel from one side of the world to the other to find that word 'retraining'. Although the word is in his speech, it appears only once in 10 long pages. Many honourable members on this side of the House have been talking about retraining because we believe it is the crux of the whole employment and unemployment area.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will be eligible after the next election.

—The Minister talks about the next election. He had better watch out; he might be for the high jump himself. In talking about training and retraining, we have heard so much about how the communique has been misrepresented. The Minister has said that he has not misrepresented the situation. Let me put it this way: He may not have misrepresented the situation but he has carefully left out some of the very fine and good points. The following statement is made on the second page of the communique:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers expressed their deep concern about the human and social implications of the extremely grave economic and social problems induced by such high levels of unemployment. They expressed their firm determination to combat unemployment in the short and medium term-
I ask honourable members to listen to this-
and to contribute to speeding up the creation of jobs in various sectors of the economy-
Also on the same page the following statement was made:
Having regard to both the challenge and potential of technological progress, Ministers stressed the need for the creation of sufficient new jobs-

The Minister left that out of his statement but it was in the communique. I would like to reinforce the Minister's statement by reading what was said at the bottom of the third page of the communique. I am sure that this part of communique was accidentally left out of the statement. The communique stated:
They agreed that the emphasis should now, wherever possible, be on measures to underpin a non-inflationary economic recovery by reducing industrial costs and encouraging investment-
Which this Government is not doing, of course-
and-
This is the point-
particularly on those to create new jobs-
Further on the following statement was made:

They agreed that it was worthwhile to discuss the merits of partly using these funds for training schemes to help the unemployed to get into new jobs; short- time work combined with partial unemployment compensation;
This aspect is mentioned again-
Temporary public jobs with a strong training element-
All of that is in the communique but the Minister conveniently left it out of his statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't read it.

—I do not think he read it either. The manpower and training policy of this Government is virtually non-existent. Total Government expenditure on manpower training and support schemes has fallen in real terms by around 44 per cent of Budget appropriations between 1975-76 and 1981-82. In fact, I will quote from a speech that the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) made on 16 March which sums up the situation very succinctly. The honourable member said:

SPEECH.PARA: The amount of expenditure by the Fraser Government on all manpower training and support programs has fallen in real terms by over 50 per cent between 1975-76 and 1980-81. Even with the increased Budget allocation of 1981-82, the decline in real terms over the life of this Fraser Government has been 44 per cent.

Job creation and employment growth have also slumped despite attention that has been given to youth programs for which there was an increase in real terms of 11 .5 per cent in the 1981-82 Budget. But such programs have had no real effect; nor have they resulted in any lasting improvement in teenage employment. Teenage unemployment has been increasing on an annual basis since November and is now over 20 per cent. It is well over 20 per cent in my area. In fact, in my electorate of Isaacs there is an unemployment rate of 12 per cent and a youth unemployment rate which well exceeds 20 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 21.2 per cent.

—I thank the honourable member. The Minister said that he expected youth unemployment world wide to rise to 17 per cent. In Australia we are far in excess of that already. We are 4 per cent to 5 per cent over the world figure which was set out in the Minister's statement. Teenage employment has been falling absolutely since around the middle of last year. In January the fall in fact was 23,200 or over 3 per cent and three-quarters of these young people were in full time jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: The United States of America and the United Kingdom have employed monetarist policies. In those countries the situation under President Reagan and Prime Minister Thatcher has become worse. The United Kingdom has three million people unemployed. As recently as today an announcement has been made that this figure has dropped fractionally because the British Government has loosened the purse strings a fraction. We on this side of the House are saying that such action should be taken here. I think the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) said yesterday that we are at least six months behind what is happening in the rest of the world. At least Mrs Thatcher has woken up to the fact that unless she does something she will go down the gurgler and that instead of three million people being unemployed there will be more like 13 million.

In this country the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and the Minister for Industrial Relations, who I am surprised has not tippy-toed in here to speak on this matter, had better wake up to what is happening and bring forward some comprehensive and constructive policies to help this country out in the whole area of the economy, wages, prices, incomes policies and the like. We just cannot isolate one from the other . Employment growth peaked at around 3.5 per cent on an annual basis in the September quarter of 1980. This was associated, of course, with escalating growth in average weekly earnings and the easing of tight government policies. I have just indicated that the British Government took such action. However, the reversal of those two influences and the tightening of the reins again after the 1980 election have been associated with a collapse in employment growth to around 1.5 per cent. So growth in this area has halved in the last 18 months.

The policies of this Government are in an absolute shambles. The Minister has come into the chamber with a rag bag collection of thoughts and cliches. He has not even quoted properly from the communique that he went 20,000 miles across the world to help formulate. I think it is an absolute disgrace. I am glad that the Minister is hiding his head because he should. The sooner this Government can bring forward some constructive economic policies which can be applied right across the board, especially in the prices, wages and incomes area, the better off will be Australian families and unemployed people who are fighting for survival under this Government. The Government should take the lead and put forward some constructive debate. Unfortunately the Government will be in office until the next election which hopefully will be held sooner rather than later. Therefore, the Government should get some good thoughts on this matter. The honourable member for Wills made an offer and we are ready to take the Government on.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ELECTRICITY SUPPLY AMENDMENT BILL 1982
