DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Fraser Government's responsibility for the worsening economic situation disclosed by the latest Confederation of Australian Industry/Bank of New South Wales report entitled 'Survey of Industrial Trends in Australia'.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More that the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia, in a very direct sense, is being de- industrialised by the Fraser Government. Over the past 12 months, the Government 's policies towards manufacturing have further worsened. The exchange rate has been overvalued. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) has called for a devaluation. Programs of incentives have been cut or threatened. Great uncertainty has been created by references to the Industries Assistance Commission which have been completely mistimed and also misconstrued. The influence of the inquiries of the Jackson Committee to Advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry and the Crawford Commission to Advise on Assistance to Industry is virtually non-existent. Government-industry consultation has been completely downgraded and, instead of earlier commitment to productivity and capacity expansion, we now have the ideology of the free market, the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and the free trade fantasyland of the back bench 'dries'. None of them is in the House at present. I wish we could have them in a debate such as this so that we could take them on head on.

SPEECH.PARA: That is only part of the present list of woes. But is it any wonder that the survey of industrial trends conducted by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Bank of New South Wales reveals that this severe downturn has occurred in the Australian manufacturing sector. At this stage I will say something about the survey. It was released last Sunday and it reveals that new orders, output and employment have fallen in the last three months. The respondents to the survey-those who helped by answering the various questionnaires-were extremely pessimistic when asked to look to the period ahead ; in fact, the most pessimistic for over eight years. The worsening economic situation revealed by this survey, which is also evident from a variety of other indicators-we do not have to rely only on this survey-is without question the result of the ineptitude and the mismanagement of the Government from which this country is suffering at present at the national level. On virtually every count it is a failure or an absence of Fraser Government policy which has led to the downturn in the survey, despite the continuing advantages and the long term prospects of the Australian economy.

At the time of the last Federal election, the Government was busily convincing itself and trying to convince everyone else-sadly, too many were convinced or the majority would have been on my side of politics with the Australian Labor Party governing this country-that the Australian economy was on the way to a boom decade in the 1980s. Surveys of resource and manufacturing projects were regularly compiled, each showing growth of billions of dollars in the total value of anticipated projects. We have not seen one of the projections for some time. The Government is now selling a very different image of the economic situation. It is trying to lower expectations to prepare Australians for harder times ahead. It is particularly concerned to create an attitude whereby the various hard pressed sections of the community will reduce their demand for what could well be a fare share of national income and government services.

These swings in the Government's rhetoric from the talk of the boom decade of the 1980s to the gloom that we are hearing now and these swings in the images that the Government paints of our economic prospects are themselves part of the economic mismanagement of the Government. The periodic raising and lowering of public expectations has done enormous damage to the social consensus in this country. Moreover, it has tended to worsen the economic cycle because the Fraser Ministry is so vulnerable to short term developments. The complete lack of longer term thinking and the complete lack of planning have meant that the Government has merely reacted to events. It is not in any way properly ordering those events.

When the economy began to experience the early benefits of resource development , the Government acted dramatically to raise expectations further, with consequent inflationary implications. Then, in a mad retreat from that, which was, of course, associated with the 1980 election, the Government instituted the tightest economic policies of its six-year period of office. Last April, almost a year ago, we had the cutbacks in the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee-the razor gang. Since that time, we have had a sharp increase in health insurance charges; we have had higher income and sales taxes; we have had the collapse of a wages policy; we have had a stringent Federal Budget; we have had severe cuts in loan funds for the States; we have had a further marked tightening of monetary policies; we have had an increase of about 2 per cent in most interest rates; and on top of all that, we have had a deliberate policy of maintaining a high value for the Australian dollar.

In his Budget Speech, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) was honest enough to say that these stringent measures were aimed at reducing inflationary pressures and would have implications for the level of economic activity and employment. There can be no doubt that the Government decided to slam on the brakes because it had absolutely lost its credibility with its deceitful wage, tax and pricing policies. It had only one weapon against inflation and that was recession. The fact that we now have entered this recession is undeniable. Twelve months of orthodox monetarist ideology has been rigidly pursued at the same time as the Government's long term commitment to manufacturing industry has been steadily diluted and now has been virtually deserted. It is complete hypocrisy for the Government now to claim that either wages or international circumstances are the major causes of the new recession. We had another attempt at this sort of selling--

TALK.START.PARA: —Buck passing.

—We had another attempt at this buck passing, as the honourable member for Canberra says, in the previous debate when the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) sought to do just that. Real wages in Australia have grown by barely one per cent in the year to December 1981, yet Australia's international competitiveness was eroded by over 10 per cent as a result of many factors including the appreciation of the exchange rate of the Australian dollar. Of course, Government budgetary decisions further directly eroded our competitiveness by a further 2 to 3 per cent during 1981. This feature that we now have of a lack of competitiveness is Government-induced to an enormous extent, yet the buck passing is such that the Government is seeking to persuade the community that the blame lies in other places. To blame wages for the collapse of confidence is ridiculous when these relative factors are considered. If there is any merit at all in the argument that future anxiety about wage levels is a problem, that can also be sheeted home to the Government. There is no wages policy in Australia and the uncertainties following the collapse of wage indexation have not led to any sensible efforts by the Government to restore any sort of wage order. Instead, even greater uncertainty is promised through the desperate politics of industrial confrontation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is equally deceptive in its attempt to blame international factors. This Confederation of Australian Industry and Bank of New South Wales survey asked the respondents to that survey to state the single most important factor limiting their production. The overwhelming majority pointed to a shortage of orders; that is, of course, inadequate demand. That is the real cause of the downturn at present. The latest statistics show that this slackness in demand exists in the domestic economy, which accounts for about 85 per cent of total demand. In the year to January retail sales grew by 1.2 per cent in real terms. That is a fall in per capita spending terms because of the growth in our population. In January private dwelling approvals were down 3.3 per cent on the previous year. Figures for the first two months of this year reveal a fall in motor vehicle registrations. There may have been a little bit of optimism in this area at the end of last year, but I repeat that for the first two months of this year the position is that the number of motor vehicle registrations is down .

As a direct result of Government policy, public sector consumption and investment spending are stagnant. These areas of spending account for more than two-thirds of the national economy. In regard to exports we have heard more of the buck passing that has been mentioned by the honourable member for Canberra ( Mrs Kelly). If it is not about wages, it is about international factors affecting the situation. That is correct to a certain extent, but the fact that exports are not growing is related to only 15 per cent of the economy and is more than offset by the one bright spot-investment in future export industries.

Clearly, it is the series of recessionary measures taken over the last 12 months by the national Government that is at the heart of present economic difficulties. In turn, these measures can be seen as the result of two more fundamental failures. The first is the failure to develop any effective anti- inflation strategy, including a prices and incomes policy. The second is the failure to take a long term view, to plan for future growth and to see periods of limited demand as opportunities for investment and training for future needs.

It is in these respects that the Fraser Government has been such an abysmal economic failure. It has a time horizon of only a few weeks. To this Government, the long term is just a series of short terms, usually with political problems rather than economic opportunities as the major focus of attention. There is every reason to expect an international economic recovery towards the end of this year or early next year; there should be. Energy prices are unlikely to fall; in fact, there remains a world-wide longer term expectation of higher energy prices, increasing by 2 per cent to 3 per cent in real terms each year, so the energy equation will begin to work in our favour.

Thus there is no reason why, apart from domestic mismanagement, Australia should not be planning and pursuing a much stronger growth path right now. I only wish that this Government would exhort President Reagan and those who are running the economic policies of the United States to follow a more appropriate economic policy in that country, which so governs the level of economic activity in the world. Instead, because that exhortation is not given and because of wrong economic domestic policies, the economy is languishing to such an extent that we are forced to listen to stories of gloom and more gloom from Government Ministers. We are also being exhorted to batten down the hatches. The Government is making the situation worse by encouraging this jawboning on the part of its Ministers and supporters.

The manufacturing sector is particularly disadvantaged by the Government's incompetence. Recent research by the Bureau of Industry Economics reveals the startling fact that in real terms there has been a net disinvestment in the manufacturing sector during the term of office of the Fraser Government. Even research and development funding has now been cut. The Budget allocation already represented a reduction in real terms, yet now it has been slashed from $50m to $33.5m. Where is the logic in a cut in industrial research funding of more than 40 per cent in real terms in a single year? This is a classic demonstration of the ad hockery and ineptitude of this Government. It also illustrates how far the Government is from governing for all Australians. Its current policies are particularly damaging to those States in which manufacturing is of vital importance. This applies in particular to Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—The honourable member for Burke is a Victorian member who will follow me in this discussion. I know he will be having something to say about this matter. The Victorian Chamber of Commerce submission to the Industries Assistance Commission inquiries in December stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Victorian economy is very sensitive to variations in the level of industry assistance . . . the Victorian economy is more likely to suffer employment losses associated with protection reductions than the Australian economy as a whole.

The mismanagement of the exchange rate and the open-ended references to the IAC have generated great pressures on the Victorian economy. One-third of manufacturing is located in that State. No fewer than 175,000 Victorian workers are employed in industries with effective rates of protection exceeding 30 per cent and 240,000 in industries with over 20 per cent protection. The Fraser Government has threatened these jobs. Clearly, we need a long term policy for the preservation and enhancement of these and other jobs. We need certainty, stability and commitment to the manufacturing sector. The Fraser Government is willing to sacrifice them all for the sake of a blind ideology and a commitment to an economic policy which is failing for its seventh consecutive year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will preach gloom and doom at the drop of a hat. Today it has put forward for discussion in this House as a matter of public importance the 'worsening economic situation'. But the changing economic situation needs to be seen in perspective. The Opposition did not make any reference to the fact, as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report recently pointed out, that from 1978 to the end of last year the real rate of economic growth in Australia-as reflected in total production, gross domestic product-was twice that of the average of the OECD countries. The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford), who is the Opposition spokesman on this issue, made no reference to the fact that over recent years employment- generated by the Government's economic policies and the enterprise and initiative of the private sector-has grown by 100,000 to 150,000 jobs per annum, or a total of some 400,000 new jobs over the past three years.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the background against which the current slow down in economic activity , which is not in dispute, should be seen. The slow down was absurdly attributed by the honourable member to the policies of this Government. In fact, the causes of the slow down are manifold and complex. Some are internal to Australia. I refer, for instance, to the unacceptably high level of industrial disputation, the recent veritable rash of strikes and bans which have added to costs, have held up export deliveries and have slowed the bringing to final agreement of major resource projects such as the North West Shelf project. It has, generally, undermined the investment climate, perhaps most notably in New South Wales. As has been exhaustively discussed in the House this afternoon, there are also excessive wage and salary claims and the push to achieve shorter working hours. If ever there was a time to shout from the roof tops the dictum of a former Labor Treasurer, Frank Crean, that 'one man's excessive wage increase costs another man his job', that time has arrived. There is indeed a heavy responsibility on the part of not only employees but also employers and wage tribunals to contain excessive cost increases. In comparison, it is worth pointing out that in the United States of America there have been recent settlements in which employees have accepted actual wage cuts in return for job security. It has never been more imperative, with both inflation and activity falling overseas, to contain any further upsurge in costs in Australia. These are some of the internal factors in the current slow down.

There are also external factors to which the honourable member for Adelaide made only the most passing reference-factors stemming from the state of the world economy-which adversely impact on Australia. While there is a slow down in Australia, there is a much stronger downswing in the world economy generally and in the United States particularly. This has seriously affected our export trade in commodities. The profitability and investment in export industries is thereby reduced; in turn this has multiplier effects which flow on to other parts of the economy. In addition, it causes difficulties with the balance of payments.

Another factor which has been widely recognised is the stabilisation of the world price of oil-in real terms, it is falling. Whilst that is advantageous in some respects it has a restraining effect on decisions in respect of some major new resource projects in the energy field, causing a slow down in the speed of development and, in some cases, even deferment. Again in the recessionary world market Australian manufacturers, to whom particularly the honourable member for Adelaide directed attention, are undoubtedly suffering from serious dumping and marginal pricing and loss-taking competition in manufactured product markets.

I would mention only one other major factor largely stemming from overseas, namely interest rates. The high level of interest rates, particularly those in the United States, inevitably impacts on interest rates here. Continuing high interest rates-which this Government, through its budgetary policy, has done everything possible to ameliorate-affect economic activity in all sorts of complex ways. High interest rates are certainly accepted on all sides as a major factor in the current weakness of the housing industry. The lower levels of activity in that industry spread out and affect many other sectors of the economy; such as the demand for furniture, consumer durables and so on.

As I say, there is a slow-down in activity. That is not in dispute. Its causes are manifold and complex. What is not true, as the Opposition in proposing this matter tries to imply, is that the total responsibility for it rests with this Government. That assertion is absurd and cannot be logically sustained for one moment. I do not suggest that the Government has not made mistakes, as the Treasurer (Mr Howard) conceded the other day. I do not suggest that there are not things which could not have been done better. In my view some things would have been done better if they had been done differently. For example-this will not please the Opposition-I would like to have seen the Government move much earlier than it has to broaden the tax base through a broad-based indirect tax with off-setting cuts in personal income tax and company tax. Had the Goverment done that, in those circumstances it may well have been in a position to retain the Trading Stock Valuation Adjustment. That would have alleviated the present very serious erosion of companies' real profits, which affects both the incentive and the capacity of companies to invest. Again the honourable member for Adelaide made reference to the significant up-valuation of the Australian dollar to last August-September. That has since been largely reversed but in the meantime it did contribute, along with the upsurge in wages, industrial disputation and the shorter hours push, to reducing the international competitive position of Australian industry with adverse consequences for activity and employment.

Having said those things, what I do assert is that the overall thrust of the Government's policy strategy has been right-and that the Government's policies have been basic in contributing to the very good performance of the Australian economy, way out in front of most of the other leading industrial nations in recent years, as I said at the outset, and still out in front, albeit currently experiencing a slow down. That is the point I want to underline.

The second point I want to underline is that in contrast the Australian Labor Party has not today in here or anywhere else offered any credible or believable alternative strategy, a point to which I will return. If there is a slow down it would have happened much earlier and would have been much worse under the economic policies that the Labor Party proposes. Further, in coping with the current difficulties and in looking ahead, if the Opposition had been dispensing things, if it had been in government, we would have been working from a much less sound, less solid and effective base than presently exists.

Let me elaborate on that. The key driving force behind the growth of the economy and the growth in employment, to which I have referred, has been the upsurge in investment spending, by which we mean spending on building new factories, new mines, resource projects and new roads and all the infrastructure that goes with them. It is that investment which is the only route to sustainable, eventually non-inflationary, long term growth and to increases in the number of jobs for Australians. I stress that this growth of business investment in recent years has restored private non-dwelling investment as a percentage of total production in the country, total GDP, to what it used to be in those high employment, strong growth, halcyon days that prevailed before the early 1970s. Last year for the first time for a decade private non-dwelling investment at about 12 per cent was on line with the long term historical average, compared with a level of 9 per cent of GDP to which it fell under the onslaught of the previous Labor Goverment. When it did so fall that meant, in the case of manufacturing industry in particular, to which the honourable member for Adelaide referred, that the capital stock in manufacturing actually fell. What I am saying is that yes, there is currently a slow down. But with this higher investment adding new and additional capital stock, and thus an enhanced supply capacity of the economy, and with the other settings right-in particular a taut monetary and fiscal policy to control inflation-we are better placed to ride out the current difficulties and then to resume economic expansion and the growth of jobs, as the world economy turns round.

I stress there will be no let up in the determination of the Government to fight inflation; and that cannot be said too often. The Government fights inflation not as an alternative to-instead of-fighting unemployment, as the Labor Party so often makes out and as the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) was saying in an earlier debate today, but in order to increase employment and growth and reduce unemployment on a sustainable basis. That is the only route to sustainable growth, to higher employment and to lower unemployment. It is inflation and higher costs which undermine competitiveness, which erode profitability and thus the capacity and the incentive to invest, because with inflation and higher costs here-the costs of construction and of employing Australians-the sums, when one projects forward a new investment and a new project, do not come out right. So it is inflation which holds back investment, the very investment which means additional jobs for Australians. As against that we have an Opposition whose first answer to overcome unemployment is to increase government spending. The honourable member for Adelaide said: ' The big factor is the shortage of orders'. He would try to get over that problem by big government spending.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the taxpayers' money.

—Yes, indeed, using the taxpayers' money. If that led to inflation, as it inevitably would, the next prong in the policy, as put by the honourable member and by other honourable members from the Opposition, is that that would be countered by an incomes policy centred around a wage compact, so-called, based on Labor's 'special relationship' with the unions. I say to this House and to the Australian people: That is wishful thinking; it is simply not credible. There is no special relationship, except that of the unions, saying to the Labor Party: 'We pay in to your funds, therefore do as we say'. There is no special relationship between the unions and the Labor Party of any value to the Australian people as a whole. A 'wages compact' and an incomes policy based on that sort of relationship is a pipe dream. It is unreal, it is not believable. It was tried on a previous occasion in 1974-75 when the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) was both head of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and President of the Australian Labor Party, and we had the most unprecedented upsurge in costs and prices in Australia's history.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —'Australian manufacturers are more pessimistic about the general business outlook for the six months ahead than they have been at any time since 1974'. This is not the conclusion of the trade union movement or the Australian Labor Party. This is the conclusion of the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Bank of New South Wales-two organisations which represent and speak on behalf of the majority of business interests in this country. They have contradicted the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Edwards) who has just spoken, and not simply the Labor Party. For these bodies to reach such a pessimistic conclusion and to advertise it, the situation must be very serious, and indeed it is. Manufacturing industry in this country is in a state of crisis, a crisis the potential consequences of which are devastating for this country.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two aspects of this crisis. Firstly, manufacturers are gloomy in their expectations of the future. They are very reluctant to invest and to increase production. The report stated:

Over half of all respondents, 54 per cent compared with 29 per cent in December and only 3 per cent a year ago, now expect a deterioration in the general business situation in Australia during the next six months. Some 41 per cent expect no change. Only 4 per cent of respondents expect an improvement, the smallest proportion recorded since June 1974.
Secondly, the actual performance of the manufacturing industry in this period has been woeful, as the report indicated. It stated:

Respondents reported a decline in output during the March quarter (-14 per cent . . .), exceeding the December survey's pessimistic forecast (-4 per cent . . .) , and representing the first reported fall in manufacturing output since September 1977. This contraction in output reflected the reduction in new orders (-18 per cent . . .) compared with December (+4 per cent . . .). Contrary to respondents' expectations in December, export deliveries (-8 per cent . . .) declined in the March quarter.

Can anyone deny that these figures are a shocking indictment of the Government's economic policy and its total neglect of the consequences of that policy on manufacturing industry? Yet what kind of response did we have from the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch)? He has not even come into the House to defend his own policies. This is the outrageous kind of response that we have had. Does he initiate urgent action to assist industry? He does not. Does he call for a revaluation of the Government's economic policies which are the direct causes of the problem? He certainly does not. Does he initiate urgent discussions with Australian manufacturers and the unions to seek solutions? He can not even conceive of that. What does he do? He issued a bland Press release in which he said:
Over the past few months there has been concern registered about the future outlook.

Nothing was said about the Minister himself being concerned and being ready to act. It was just simply a statement that there has been some concern. Let me tell the Minister that this attitude just shows his contempt for the millions of people working in manufacturing whose jobs are being threatened by his Government's policies, not to mention the hundreds of thousands of unemployed people who seek work in the manufacturing industry.

The inaction of the Minister for Industry and Commerce is particularly hurtful when one realises that he is a senior member of the Liberal Party in Victoria because it is in his own State of Victoria that manufacturing employment has been traditionally high. As much as 23.5 per cent of the work force is in manufacturing compared with a national average of 17.8 per cent. Yet it is this man, together with his mates in the reactionary Liberal Government of Victoria, who has presided over the biggest slump in the manufacturing industry in that State's history. From June 1976 to June 1980, 19,794 jobs were lost in manufacturing industry in Victoria-a reduction of 4.74 per cent. Many of these jobs were in Geelong, Ballarat and Bendigo. These and other decentralised areas have suffered dramatically from the manufacturing crisis. God knows what is going to happen to them if the present policies continue.

Of course, the Minister, in his Press release, brought up the same ritual claim which has been made over and over by the conservatives here today about this matter-that is, to blame the union movement and so-called excessive wage increases, shorter working hours and strike action. So again the blame for the present Government's ills is put on workers and their families who are merely seeking a restoration of their living standards through increases in wages.

The Opposition does not deny that sometimes wage pressures can have a negative impact on the economy but one needs to ask: Where do these pressures come from? Are they merely the consequence of the manipulation of workers by evil union leaders, as the conservatives would have us believe, or is it simply the case that every worker is now so consumed by greed that he or she cares nothing for the general welfare and merely pursues selfish ends? Whilst that might be the callous view of human nature which the conservatives ascribe to-a view which is matched by the heartlessness of their policies-the Labor Party has a different view. We reject this explanation. As everyone knows, workers are seeking increases and are taking industrial action because government pressure led to the end of wage indexation. Workers have been forced to take action to keep up with the dramatically increased costs of living and to offset massive increases in taxes imposed by this Government. The increased wages pressures are, therefore, the direct result of the Government's policies. Yet, this Government has the affrontery to blame the workers for that situation.

Any sensible government, rather than engaging in nonsensical rhetoric, would seek to develop a coherent wages policy based on co-operation with the union movement. Instead, this Government's only action in industrial relations is to introduce absurd union bashing legislation which will merely divide the nation further and create more strikes. It is clear what the machiavellian plot of this Government is. It seeks to destroy manufacturing industry by forcing a war with workers and with the union movement. It knows that this will be the consequence of that particular strategy.
Let us look at the real causes of the crisis in manufacturing industry. Let us look at the report itself which said:
Insufficiency of new orders during the quarter was nominated by most respondents as the major constraint on increased production. Excess capacity increased as a result of slackening market demand.

The single, most important reason for the reduction in demand is the inability of ordinary people to pay for goods and services. It is quite clear that reductions in real wages will always result in reductions in economic growth, contrary to the absurd theories of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Berowra. He mentioned that in fact there has been some economic growth in the last year and a half. He forgets that if one takes into account the overall period of this Government one finds that growth has been less than 3 per cent while inflation has occurred at an average rate of 11 per cent. This Government has talked about controlling inflation and giving us growth. How long do we have to wait for this so-called policy to work? In fact, we will be waiting forever if we have to wait for this Government's policies to work.

As I mentioned, the single most important reason for reduction in demand is the Government's policy. The Government, of course, does not care about manufacturing. It wants to destroy that sector altogether, as is evident from its recently released motor car policy. The reason, of course, is that the Government is simply the pawn of the big financial interests and the foreign owned mining interests which do not care about the manufacturing area at all. There is no attempt to protect employment. There is simply a long run strategy to run down manufacturing through continuous reductions in protection. The lack of demand is not, however, the only cause of this problem. Last year the Bureau of Industry Economics produced a report entitled 'The Long Run Impact of Technological Change on Australian Industry'. That report, based on optimistic assumptions of growth in the economy at an annual rate of 4.5 per cent-much more than this Government can achieve-nevertheless predicted that the manufacturing sector's share of gross domestic product will fall dramatically by 1990. The reasons for this are: Firstly, technological changes and, secondly, continuous reduction in protection. Unless dramatic action is taken, we will see those predictions coming true. In fact, they will be worse because we will not achieve anything like the overall growth rate that is predicted in the report and we will see manufacturing industry being destroyed. What does the Government do? It simply leaves it up to the so-called free market to solve the problems. It is time that a coherent alternative policy was developed rather than sticking to the present policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradfield Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter before the House has been brought on for debate by the Australian Labor Party and refers to a report prepared by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Bank of New South Wales. The survey which led to the report indicated a poor economic result in the March quarter and a June quarter expectation which suggests some further contraction. I put it to honourable members and I put it to the people that that report does not spell economic disaster for Australia, as the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) and the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) are endeavouring to convey to the Australian people. If honourable members were to study that report, they would find that Australia is doing quite well under very adverse economic conditions. They would see that one of the reasons that this economic condition exists in the world today-this is well known by people-is that world manufacturing capacity exceeds demand at the present time. Yet the honourable member for Adelaide talked about mismanagement; he talked about orthodox monetary ideology. None of that would come from that report. I suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the economic situation in Australia today is very much improved and is far better than it was because of the management of this Government over the last six years. I suggest to those people who care to read the transcript of the speech just delivered by the honourable member for Burke that if they study and analyse some of the programs he suggested they will realise that if we were to adopt those programs we would face an unbelievable economic disaster in this country, the extent of which would exceed any economic disaster we have seen in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the Government's action since 1976 has greatly cushioned the effect on Australia of the worsening world economy. Since 1976 we have had to take hard economic options, not all of which have been popular with the community. Often correct and hard economic measures are unpopular and difficult to take. But they certainly have enhanced Australia's economic foundation. As I said, our situation is most favourable in the context of the present world recession. Today many countries, in particular the United Kingdom and the United States of America, are recognising the policies that we put forward in 1976. The honourable member for Adelaide mentioned the Reagan policies. President Reagan had the wrong economic policies when he came to power. Evidence shows that he is now moving round to adopting economic policies that we adopted in Australia six years ago. The Thatcher Government of the United Kingdom is coming to the same conclusions. If honourable members were to study the new policies of those two governments they would find that they correspond with the policies this Government adopted years ago. Let us look at what we have done and what our policies are. We recognise the importance of a lower inflation rate. I quote from a book written by Professor M. G. Porter of the Monash University in Australia:
the only real means for ensuring lower interest rates-
This is of concern at the moment-
is the sustained achievement of lower rates of monetary growth and associated . . . reductions in the rate of inflation.

Is it any wonder, when we have leading economists such as that talking about the importance of inflation, that it has been the cornerstone of our monetary policies over the years? Further on in the report Professor Porter states:
those professing concern for social equity in the community should insist (a) that inflation be brought under control by moderating monetary growth . . .

I repeat: 'Those professing social equity in the community'. The Labor Opposition professes to be concerned with social equity. This Government is certainly concerned with social equity. Yet an analysis of the Opposition's policies shows that they would cause inflation and would do the reverse to creating social equity in the community; they would cause great social inequity.

Another cornerstone of our policies over the years of course has been control of the money supply. The importance of that is emphasised by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. Campbell talks about deregulation in certain areas and the Committee recommends deregulation in some areas. But control of the money supply is one of the areas in which Campbell does not recommend deregulation; in fact, he recommends that the Government should always have a monetary supply target. We do have that.

The policy of our Government has been to control the growth of the Public Service, the public sector and government spending. That is a correct policy, but it is the complete reverse of the Australian Labor Party's policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Big government.

—As the honourable member for Berowra said, it wants big government , more taxes, plenty of spending. If those policies were adopted the whole economic situation would be altered and Australia would lose the advantage created by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention another point. Manufacturing industry has been the cornerstone of the speeches of the honourable member for Adelaide and the honourable member for Burke in this debate. They said that we are trying to destroy the manufacturing industry. The honourable member for Burke, in his read speech, spoke about the Government's motor vehicle policy. Our policy on manufacturing industry has been another cornerstone of our policies in our six years of economic control in Australia. We have not neglected manufacture. We have introduced measures such as the investment allowance, research and development grants, export grants, just to name a few. We use our tariff policies to move gradually towards less protection and a less restrictive situation but at the same time they allow an orderly transfer of employment and resources to meet the changing demands of the Australian consumer. If we analyse our tariff policies we find that we are modifying protection, which the consumer wants, but we are doing it in a way that will allow Australian industry to meet future demands and future change.

In the debate the Opposition has raised the Victorian situation-I guess because an election is to be held there. I mention the New South Wales power situation. The Opposition refers in its matter of public importance to 'The Fraser Government's responsibility for the worsening economic situation'. No single factor in the economy today has done any greater harm to Australia's manufacturing capacity and our economy than has the mismanagement of the electricity supply in New South Wales. Factories are coming to a halt, programs are being cancelled. There has been no greater contributing factor. Unfortunately for Australia, we will see more of this as years go by. Our industries are facing disaster because of mismanagement by the New South Wales Labor Party and Labor Government.

I turn from the situation in New South Wales to some of the economic statistics that the Opposition speakers have distorted to support their claim of economic disaster. I quote a few summaries from the most up to date 'Round-up of Economic Statistics' published for the Treasury in March 1982. It is now March 1982. The publication states:
Employment growth has slowed; in the three months to January 1982, total employment was 1.5 per cent higher than in the three months to January 1981.

The employment growth rate has slowed down but it is 1.5 per cent higher than it was. I ask does that constitute economic disaster? Yet in the six years that we have been in government, because of the policies of this Government, the total level of employment in Australia has increased by half a million people. Let us look at some of the other things that these economic statistics state. The growth in retail sales appears to have eased. That is not very good news. But sales were 12.4 per cent higher in the three months to January 1982 than the three months to January 1981, which is roughly the rate of inflation. Is that an economic disaster? The honourable member for Adelaide mentioned new motor vehicle registrations. The Treasury statistics show that new motor vehicle registrations have remained strong. The number of registrations in January, seasonally adjusted, was 11.2 per cent above the number in January 1981. Does that indicate an economic disaster? Mr Deputy Speaker, I put it to you that the matter of public importance put forward by the Australian Labor Party Opposition is nothing more than a fraud.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of Disabled
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers.
Rights of Disabled
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The failure of the Federal Government to seek information from the census re disabled people-i.e. partial or total disability-to enable for adequate planning of, and for, types of services needed by disabled people to be undertaken.

2. The failure of the Federal Government to lead the way in employment of disabled people by employing a greater number of such people within the Commonwealth Public Service-note the small number currently employed within the Service.

3. The wastage of the Federal Government funds perpetuating large, bureaucratic institutions and organisations where there are often few disabled people on their boards and little emphasis is placed on consumer participation in decision making.
4. The failure of the Federal Government to encourage independence of disabled people, or to develop ''normalised'' support systems-attendant care.
5. The failure of the Federal Government to provide ''non-institutionalised'' specialised accommodation for those people who would not be able to benefit from , or cope with attendant care.
6. Failure by the Federal Government to alter, or create a ''disability'' allowance means test free for all disabled people-this would assist with necessary equipment and mobility costs.
7. Failure to provide a national compensation scheme thus saving time and enabling people to be automatically covered in the event of a disability.
8. Failure by the Federal Government to abolish tariffs on all equipment available to the disabled-e.g. Optacon.
9. Mismanagement of Federal I.Y.D.P. Funds-e.g. non-receipt by some States of funds through unresolved negotiations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that immediate action be taken to remedy the above stated and that the Federal Government recognise that disabled people are citizens who should have equal rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Free,Mrs Kelly,Mr Les McMahon,Mr Mountford and Mr Wallis.

PETITION.TITLE: Perth Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that total annual aircraft movements into and out of Perth airport are expected to more than double over the next fourteen years.
Your petitioners note that this will produce a dramatic increase in noise pollution in the surrounding suburbs, particularly those directly beneath flight paths.
Your petitioners further note that unlike Great Britain, Australia has no legislation to allow payments of compensation for injurious affection.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(1) That the Minister for Transport implement a curfew banning traffic movements at Perth Airport between 11.00 p.m. and 6.00 a.m.
(2) That legislation be introduced to allow payment for injurious affection, including compensation for costs of insulation of private and public buildings.
(3) That the planned parallel runway be constructed immediately so as to direct air traffic over the non residential area at Newburn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the present hunt for Harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhuman manner.
That the population of Harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the Harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from the Harp seal, Pagophilus groenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth; that we deplore the fact that the unemployed are not allowed or encouraged to make significant earnings over and above their unemployment benefits without substantial loss of their unemployment benefits.
We are very concerned that the allowable earnings for unemployment beneficiaries remains unchanged at the 1969 level-$3 for under 18 years and $6 for over 18 years.
This discrimination is a further example of the government's harsh and insensitive treatment towards the unemployed and their families, and creates unnecessary divisions within Australian society.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should decide to provide all the unemployed with the right to earn at least $30 over and above the unemployment benefit before they suffer a reduction in their benefit.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Planning Association: Rural Educator Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That many thousands of people in Wagga Wagga and district who have had access to the Service of the NSW Family Planning Association through a rural educator, express their concern that this service has been abolished due to reduction of funding to the Family Planning Association by the Federal Government and seek the necessary funds to re-establish this position.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Members of the House of Respresentatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the course of the Community Youth Support Scheme in Circular Head.
Your petitioners therefore humbly beg that Parliament take positive action to prevent the closure of the Community Youth Support Scheme in Circular Head.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled in the House of Representatives.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognize that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognize that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
i. a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
ii. subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
iii. farmer unrest at seed prices,
iv. monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
v. increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
We are concerned over the extreme cruelty involved in the Harp seal kill and the great uncertainty of the remaining population of the Harp seal.

Your petitioners humbly pray that pressure is brought to bear on the Canadian Government to stop the Harp seal kill, and in doing so, not only end this cruel slaughter but also the possible extinction of the Harp seal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Grey respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned about the annual bloody slaughter of the baby harp seals and the frightening drop in their numbers from 3.3 million in 1954 to some few hundred thousand at present.
It must be well known by this time, to the Canadian Government that world opinion is strongly opposed to their action on this most controversial issue.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will personally lobby the Canadian Government against the abhorrent slaughter of those totally innocent victims. If not to completely abolish the slaughter, then at least to cut the quota so the seals may have a chance to refurbish their numbers.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Highway, North Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of North Queensland respectfully showeth:
that the National Highway is the responsibility of the Federal Government,
the Bruce Highway in North Queensland is of inferior standard for a National Highway,
Queensland has suffered a 15 per cent disadvantage over other States during the past ten years in road funding,
and the state of the Highway is deteriorating as maintenance expenditure is insufficient to maintain even the present standard.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will allocate sufficient expenditure, to raise the standard of the National Highway in North Queensland to Department of Transport standards, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, within ten years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth that the decision to close Latrobe CYSS centre was a mistake by the Federal Government for the following reasons:

1. Latrobe CYSS is a viable project meeting the needs of up to thirty unemployed youth under the age of 25 out of a target population of 116, each week. Over half of them are involved in training in a variety of vocations on a regular basis.

2. This centre caters not only for the town of Latrobe, but also for the unemployed youth in eight outlying districts in and around the Labrobe Municipality. The nearest alternative CYSS centre is two hour's walk from Latrobe, farther in five districts, and there are no bus, tram or train services in any of these areas. Less than one in 14 young unemployed have their own cars in this area (Mike Blizzard, TASYOUTH Div. of State Dept of Social Welfare).
3. The Management Committee has already taken steps to insure that this centre will operate effectively under the new guidelines.
Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Government to refund Latrobe CYSS immediately, and your petitioners as in duty bound will forever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission: Melbourne Showband
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Australian Parliament as in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that:
As regular viewers and listeners of the ABC Melbourne Showband we were disappointed to learn of the dismissal of seventeen members of this outstanding orchestra.

We have had a great deal of pleasure over the past eight years viewing and listening to this band's fine music. It is the only full-time light orchestra in Australia and we are disgusted to think that such talented musicians should be dismissed in this manner.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to rescind this decision and make more money available for the continuance of the full Showband and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Minister for Communications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned members of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union respectfully showeth:

That the Prime Minister of Australia should seek the resignation of the Minister for Communications. Failing this the Prime Minister should dismiss the aforementioned Minister. We seek this action following the Minister's apparent lack of concern for the welfare of his employees in the Australian Postal Commission and the Australian Telecommunications Commission.

Staff ceilings imposed as directed by the Minister show that the future employment security of Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union members is jeopardised. It is our educated estimation that these staff ceilings will also affect the standard of service provided to the public by the two commissions.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Prime Minister will take immediate action to abide by our desire.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Exchange, Sheringa, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain electors of the Division of Grey respectively showeth:

(1) That the manual telephone exchange at Sheringa is closed from 9 p.m. to 9 a .m. and from 1-2 p.m. daily and also from noon on Saturdays until 9 a.m. on Mondays as well as one whole Thursday per month and therefore in times of emergency such as fire, accident or sickness, subscribers have no means of fast communication during these periods of closure.
(2) That the Sheringa area is prone to fires on account of frequent thunderstorm activity.
(3) That Sheringa is farming and grazing district and stock agents are often inconvenienced because they cannot make contact with farmers other than when the exchange is open.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will urge that the conversion date of the Sheringa exchange to automatic operation be brought forward and placed on high priority.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Commonwealth of Australia Branch delegation to the twenty-seventh Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference, held in Fiji in October 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is not my intention to delay the House unduly. As leader of the Australian delegation, I simply want to take advantage of the opportunity in the first instance to express my genuine appreciation of the staunch and loyal support of all members of the delegation during the Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference. That loyalty and the extraordinary unanimity of view covered all the State parliamentary delegates as well. SPEECH.PARA: The report itself, particularly the summary of proceedings in the appendix, will acquaint members with the character of the conference.
