DEBATE.TITLE: QUEENSLAND ABORIGINALS AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS (SELF-MANAGEMENT AND LAND RIGHTS) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is historic. It seeks to exercise the full power of the Commonwealth to make laws for the people of any race, including people of the Aboriginal race . It seeks to override the Government of the State of Queensland in respect of the ownership and control of land by Aboriginal people of that State. Most importantly, it has been passed by the Senate, which is the House of this Parliament with at least a theoretical responsibility for safeguarding State interests. In this case the Senate has taken the view that the interests of the Aboriginal people of Queensland are greater than the interests of the Government of Queensland.

Interestingly, the Bill was passed by the Senate on the voices. There was no division at any stage during the Senate's consideration of the Bill or the amendments agreed to during the Committee stage. Presumably the Government did not want to be embarrassed by the revelation of support for this measure from among its own ranks. From their remarks we do know that at least two Government senators would have voted for the Bill. We also know at least six of the ten Senators from Queensland would have voted for the Bill. That is, a clear majority for the representatives of the Queensland people, elected under one of the fairest systems imaginable, support the view that the Commonwealth should intervene to override the Government of what the state rights fanatics are fond of calling the Sovereign State of Queensland.

We are unsure of the views of the occasionally dewy-eyed Senator Martin from Queensland. This sometime crusader for progressive causes was strangely mute during the entire debate in the Senate. She was apparently caught in a conflict of disloyalty-either abandon the interests of a rotten and unrepresentative Government of which her party is an enthusiastic member, or abandon the interests of the Aboriginal people of her State for whom she has from time to time pretended some sympathy. But when it came to the point she apparently could not summon the courage to declare her position. Her conflict was resolved in cowardly silence. Not so her colleague, Senator Bonner. He is to be congratulated for making the choice in favour of the Aboriginal people of Queensland. Even he, who after all has been extraordinarily tolerant and forgiving of the Queensland Government, has decided that there is no point in expecting that Government to discover sufficient decency to resolve the problems of land rights in that State.

The Queensland Government has shown no intention of providing land rights. In fact, it has set its face implacably against that course. That is why Senator Ryan, on behalf of the Opposition, introduced this Bill. She deserves our congratulations for the way in which she has taken this initiative and for the way in which she has taken account of the views of Queensland Aboriginals not only in the original drafting of the Bill but also in the formulation of amendments, the need for which arose as a result of her extensive consultations in Queensland.

Let me provide the justification for this Bill. There are in Queensland two major statutes governing the lives of Aborigines on Aboriginal reserves; namely, the Aborigines Act and the Torres Strait Islanders Act, passed in 1971 and amended in 1974, 1975 and 1979. These laws contain many features obnoxious to the Aborigines who have to live under them and, one hopes, obnoxious to anyone in Australia who has any concern for the outrageous abuses of human rights which these laws enforce.

Action was taken by the last Federal Labor Government to outlaw the worst of these abuses with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act. However, many objectionable provisions remain. A campaign against these Queensland Acts, as they have been known, has been waged ever since their enactment over 10 years ago. They have been the focus of Aboriginal hostility in Queensland. In what I imagine the Premier of Queensland thought was a clever device, he announced in the context of the last State election that he would repeal these laws. However, what he really intended was to abolish the reserves to which these laws related. In this way Aboriginal occupancy of the reserve lands would be even more tenuous. Proposals for leasehold tenure were raised-variously 50-year or perpetual leases. The Premier' s action, however, was far too cute. What purported to be action to benefit the Aboriginal people of Queensland was in fact a ruse to disguise his continual rejection of legitimate claims for land rights. The issue became urgent in the middle of last year when the hopelessly inadequate leasehold proposals were formally foreshadowed. The Aboriginal people rejected them and called for Commonwealth intervention. The Commonwealth did nothing and so the Opposition, the Australian Labor Party, undertook to sponsor this Bill to provide for the intervention sought by the Aboriginal people of Queensland.

This Bill is specifically designed to respond to the announced intention of the Queensland Government to abolish Aboriginal reserves in Queensland. It will make possible the granting of freehold title to Aboriginals for land which constituted Aboriginal reserves as at 31 March 1978. The major provisions of the Bill are: An optional system of self-management which will not be able to be circumvented by the Queensland Government; the ability to make a land rights claim in respect of the reserves; power for the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to acquire the claimed land from the Queensland Government under the Lands Acquisition Act of 1955; the setting up of an Aboriginal land trust in respect of each reserve acquired; minerals are to remain the property of the State but mining is to be allowed only if either the land trust agrees or where both Houses of the national Parliament pass a resolution that mining must go ahead in the national interest; and, where mining does proceed, the Aboriginal owners of the land will be entitled to compensation.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was addressing my remarks to the Bill which the House has received from the Senate in relation to the proposal to provide for Aboriginal land rights in Queensland. I said at the outset that this Bill is historic but in a sense it proposes no new principles which have not already been accepted by both the Opposition and the Government in this place. It is the extension of those principles in a workable and determined way which is new. The principle of overriding State laws in relation to Aborigines was contained in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders ( Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act. The principle of Aboriginal self-management is contained in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Reserves and Communities Self-Management) Act and the principle of land rights is contained in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. The Bill before us seeks to assemble and extend the principles of existing legislation to provide land rights and self-management for Queensland Aboriginals.

SPEECH.PARA: I should point out that the provisions in this Bill do not attempt to deal with the question of land rights of Queensland Aboriginals in its entirety, much less with the general question of land for Aborigines living in other States of Australia and the Australian Capital Territory. Those questions remain to be addressed and it is not intended that this legislation will preclude any further legislative action to provide Aboriginal land rights in Queensland or elsewhere. This Bill applies only to reserve lands. The 3 million-odd hectares comprising the land area of Queensland Aboriginal reserves amount to 1.8 per cent of the total Queensland land area of 172 million hectares. When the various Torres Strait Island reserves are added to the Aboriginal reserves the percentage of Queensland land areas affected is approximately 2 per cent. Surely there can be no argument that the claim of 2 per cent of Queensland for Aborigines is anything other than a reasonable one.

The Bill relies on the power of the Commonwealth, bestowed by an amendment to the Constitution passed by all States by substantial majorities in 1967, to make laws in respect of people of the Aboriginal race. It was on this power that this Government based its attempts to provide for self-management at Mornington Island and Aurukun. That law was circumvented, just as this Government apparently intended it to be, by the actions of the Queensland Government when it abolished the reserves to which the law was to apply. The defect of the Act was that it left the ownership of the land in the hands of the Queensland Government.

A committee of the Senate examined and reported on the validity and intended operation of the Act. Referring to the constitutional status of the Act, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs said at paragraph 40 of its report:

The Committee is of the view that the legislation clearly falls within the scope of the power conferred upon Parliament by section 51 (xxvi) of the Constitution . . . Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders as defined in the Act are 'people of any race'. A law allowing self-management and control of their affairs is a law 'with respect to' such people. Even if it should be necessary to go further and demonstrate that the Act is a 'special' law in the sense that it relates to Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders as such, the Committee is satisfied that the Act meets this requirement.
At this point I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard several paragraphs of the Committee's report in relation to its views on section 51 ( xxvi) of the Constitution.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
(4) Views of the committee on Section 51 (xxvi)

12. In general, the Committee is of the opinion that the Commonwealth has plenary (though concurrent) power to make laws with respect to Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who reside in Queensland. In accordance with established principles of constitutional interpretation, discussed in para. 8, the words of section 51 (xxvi) of the Constitution are to be read in their natural sense; any limitations upon the power must be found within the terms of the Constitution, either expressly or by implication.
(a) Express Limitations

13. Along with all other powers contained in section 51 of the Constitution, the power to make laws with respect to the people of any race is conferred ' subject to [the] Constitition' and must therefore be exercised according to limitations expressed in the Constitution, such as sections 92 (freedom of interstate trade, commerce and intercourse), 116 (freedom of religion) and 117 ( freedom from discrimination based on State residence). None of these appear to be in issue in the present reference.
(b) Implied limitations

14. The power conferred by section 51 (xxvi) must also be read in conjuction with other provisions of the Constitution, including other heads of power in section 51 itself. In so doing, the High Court may impose limitations upon broad words of the Constitution by implication. The scope of a general power may be confined in order to give effect to limitations placed upon the scope of a more specific power. The position was summarized by Menzies J in Strickland v. Rocla Concrete Pipes Ltd (1971) 124 CLR 468, at p. 507:

Each subject of enumeration is not exclusive of the others and a limit upon one cannot be inferred merely from the existence of another of more particular scope . Nevertheless, when there is to be found a limit in the definition of one subject matter the others should not be construed as enabling Parliament, by legislation on a different subject matter, to override that express restriction. Of this s. 51(xxxi) provides the simplest example, but in Bank of New South Wales v. The Commonwealth [(1948) 76 CLR 1] there is to be found another example , namely a limitation upon s. 51 (xx).

This principle is relevant to section 51 (xxvi) of the Consititution in so far as it demonstrates that the power to make laws with respect to the people of any race may not be exercised so as to acquire property free of the restrictions imposed by section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution. Beyond that, it is not clear what other limitations could possibly be placed upon section 51 (xxvi) merely by reading that provision in the context of other paragraphs of section 51. The inclusion of section 51 (xxvi) in the Constitution as a separate head of power becomes meaningless if it is given no sphere of operation beyond the other provisions of section 51. The untenability of that approach to interpretation was recognised by the High Court in a somewhat different context in Strickland v . Rocla Concrete Pipes Ltd (above), when it was affirmed that section 51 (xx) of the Consitition would not be limited by implication to corporations engaged in inter-State trade: per Barwick CJ at p. 497, per Menzies J at 509, per Gibbs J at p. 523.
(c) 'The people'

15. The submission of the Western Australian Government raised the question whether the power conferred by section 51 (xxvi) upon the Commonwealth Parliament is merely a power to make laws with respect to the people of any race generally, but not with respect to a specified segment of such people (Annexure F, p. 5). Some support for this view may be derived from the wording of section 51 (xxvi), which refers to 'The people of any race' rather than to 'people of any race'. The Committee feels that the High Court is unlikely to adopt this narrow and somewhat strained interpretation of section 51 (xxvi). It is not a necessary consequence of the phraseology of section 51 (xxvi), and does not appear to the Committee to be consistent with the approach of reading the Constitution 'naturally in the light of the circumstances in which it was made': see para. 8, above.
(d) 'Race'

16. The Oxford English Dictionary variously defines the word as meaning 'a group of persons . . . connected by common descent or origin', 'a tribe, nation or people regarded as of common stock', 'the fact or condition of belonging to a particular people or ethnic stock; the qualities etc. resulting from this', and 'a group of persons . . . having some common feature or features' (volume VIII, p. 87). There is considerable difficulty in determining a single, precise meaning of 'race' in section 51 (xxvi) of the Constitution. This problem may well arise in the context of deciding whether a particular person is a member of a nominated race. The problem is compounded in the case of a person of mixed blood, that is to say, a person whose ancestry comprises more than one tribe, nation or other group of people. There appear to be two basic approaches towards determining the 'race' of such a person. The first is largely subjective: it concentrates upon the assertion made by the person regarding his or her race, provided that the assertion is generally accepted by recognized members of that race. The difficulty with this approach lies in the latitude which it affords a person to 'select' a desired race. It may be doubted whether the High Court would allow such flexibility. The second method is objective; it concentrates upon the origin of a person in fact. The difficulty here is that there is no inherently correct minimum which may be applied to exclude people from a race. Why should a one-eighth ancestry necessarily be insufficient to allow membership of a race, as compared to a one-fourth, or even a one-half ancestry? It is perhaps not unlikely that the High Court will seek to avoid all of these problems by refusing to adopt any single criterion as a determinant of race. Instead, the Court may well decide that race is a question of fact to be decided in any particular case by a consideration of all relevant factors, subjective and objective.

17. It is not incumbent upon the Committee to reach a conclusion upon the meaning of 'race' in section 51 (xxvi) of the Constitution. The terms of reference merely require an opinion on whether Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders fall within the ambit of legislative power conferred by the section. There seems little room for doubt in the case or both Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. So far as Aboriginals are concerned, the inclusion of the exception of 'the aboriginal race in any State' from 'race' before the 1967 amendment of section 51 (xxvi) clearly illustrates that, whatever meaning is finally attributed to 'race', it includes Aboriginals. The effect of the amendment was to broaden the ambit of the section by deleting this express exception. This approach to interpretation of section 51 (xxvi) of the Constitution is not available in the case of Torres Strait Islanders. Nevertheless, it would seem that, regardless of the criteria ultimately adopted by the High Court to determine 'race', Torres Strait Islanders would meet the description of 'people of any race'.
(e) 'It is deemed necessary'

18. It is for the Commonwealth Parliament to decide whether it is necessary to make special laws for the people of a particular race. The Constitution provides no basis for limiting the discretion which may be exercised by the Parliament in making such a decision. Although section 51 (xxvi) falls short of specifying that the determination is to be made 'by Parliament', the practical operation of the section demands implication of those words.
(f) 'Special laws'

19. Either one of two consequences may flow from the inclusion of the reference to 'special laws' in section 51 (xxvi) of the Constitution. The phrase may be viewed as having a limiting effect upon the scope of power conferred upon the Parliament, in that the power extends to making only those laws which meet the description of 'special'. Presumably, 'special laws' in this context would mean laws having a particular connection with the 'people of any race' for whom Parliament had deemed such laws to be necessary. In other words, the legislative capacity of the Parliament would not only be limited but would also vary according to the particular race chosen and the matters which the High Court viewed as being 'special' to that race. On the other hand, the inclusion of the reference to 'special laws' may be viewed as having no limiting effect upon the scope of legislative power, the phrase being merely descriptive of laws applicable to a restricted category of people. This approach is suggested by the distinction between general and special Acts of Parliament, the former referring to laws applying to the population at large, the latter referring to laws applying to a defined segment of the population. Any laws enacted pursuant to section 51 (xxvi) of the Constitution would necessarily fall within the latter category, by virtue of their nexus with 'the people of any race'.

20. The Committee is of the opinion that the second of the above interpretations is required by the wording of section 51 (xxvi) of the Constitution. To adopt the first approach is to ignore the opening words of the provision:
The Parliament shall . . . have power to make laws . . . with respect to:
(xxvi) The people of any race for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws.

Stated differently, the first approach does not take account of the fact that Parliament is given power to make laws with respect to the nominated matter: on the contrary, it treats the provision as saying that the Parliament merely has power to make special laws with respect to that subject matter.

21. Nevertheless, the issue may not be entirely free from doubt. The Committee therefore feels it appropriate to add that, even if the power of Parliament is confined to making 'special laws', there is considerable scope for Commonwealth legislation allowing Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who live on reserves in Queensland to manage and control their own affairs. No general answer can be given to the question of which statutes constitute 'special laws'. That is an issue which can only be decided on a case-by-case basis. To take but one example, the Committee notes that Blackburn J in Milirrpum v. Nabalco Pty Ltd (1970) CLR 141, found that the plaintiff Aboriginals had a 'religious relationship' with land, and that land formed the basis of their social organization (pp. 165-171). In such circumstances, it seems to the Committee that Commonwealth legislation which provided, for example, for acquisition of an appropriate interest in land as part of a scheme for self-management of the affairs of Aboriginals would be 'special' in the required sense.
(g) 'With respect to'

22. By way of concluding this section of the Report, the Committee recognizes that a law enacted pursuant to section 51 (xxvi) of the Constituton must satisfy the ordinary requirement of being 'with respect to' the subject matter of the power, namely, 'the people of any race . . .' Not every law which has some impact however slight, upon Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders will come within this category. Whether a particular law does so or not depends finally upon the provisions of that law. The High Court has carefully refrained from providing precise (and thereby inflexible) rules to govern this process of characterization. The requirement is finally a matter of degree.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister and the House. The Committee also concluded that 'the constitutional conception underlying the principles and structure of the legislation are consistent with the proper responsibilities of the Commonwealth.' It went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The effectiveness of the Act is very limited . . . the effective operation of the Act is . . . dependent upon the acquiescence of the Queensland Government.

That is why, of course, the Act failed. The Queensland Government would not acquiesce and the Commonwealth, in the face of that failure to acquiesce on the part of the Queensland Government, did not take the sensible and necessary action to provide for the compulsory operation of the Act in spite of the failure of the Queensland Government to co-operate. The Committee further concluded as follows:

The Committee notes that, since the amendment of the Constitution in 1967 to give the Commonwealth Parliament power to make laws with respect to Aboriginals, most attempts have failed to achieve any co-operative arrangement with the Queensland Government regarding management and control of the affairs of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in that State and the current agreement in respect of local government arrangements cannot, as yet, be seen as successful or as generally acceptable to the residents of Aurukun and Mornington Island. The Committee accordingly bases its recommendations regarding Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in Queensland on the assumption that co- operation between the Commonwealth and Queensland is not likely to provide a full and sufficient discharge of Commonwealth obligations to Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in Queensland and that some unilateral action by the Commonwealth will therefore be likely to be necessary. In cases where the effective management and control of their own affairs by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders requires the continued occupation of specific lands by those people, the Committee considers that some acquisition of property must form part of the legislative scheme.

The Committee pointed out the fact that in exercising its power the Commonwealth enjoyed very considerable flexibility in devising schemes for management and control of their own affairs by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders incorporating acquisition of appropriate proprietary rights and it said that the Commonwealth should enact statutes which take account of the particular circumstances of the separate communities in Queensland. In fact, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) pointed out in the Senate, the Committee believed that a single statute designed to deal with all the circumstances may not be appropriate to all situations. Of course, the Minister very quaintly picked out this one slight qualification of the Senate Committee in support of his argument that the Bill proposed in the Senate, subsequently passed in the Senate and now before us was an inappropriate response to the question of providing land rights to Aborigines in Queensland. However, in doing so he ignored the overwhelming thrust of the Committee's recommendations and the conclusions of its examination which pointed to the need for unilateral action on the part of the Commonwealth in a way which involved the acquisition of land on behalf of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in that State. So I think the Minister was less than fair in the way in which he singled out this aspect.

However, we do not disagree with the notion that there should be particular responses to the various circumstances which apply in Queensland, but in the absence of a determination by this Government to exercise its power it is not possible to devise arrangements for the variety of circumstances which exist throughout Queensland. We would, of course, not proceed with this Bill if the Government demonstrated any interest in pursuing such a course. It was either shortsightedness or plain deception on the part of this Government which resulted in the self-management exercise failing and now it is political gutlessness which prevents this Government effectively dealing with the proven intransigence of the Queensland Government.

In the debate in the Senate the lame, almost sulking attitude of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was indeed instructive. This Minister, who began in this portfolio with such promise, revealed what I imagined to be his true colours. His opposition, and I take it it is also the opposition of the Government, was based on the assertions that this Bill is, to quote him, 'premature, ill- considered, poorly drafted and based on the misapprehension that Commonwealth intervention is both necessary and desirable or that it is necessary now'. Let me deal with these criticisms. Firstly he says the legislation is premature. I must say that is pretty breathtaking. Does he want the Aboriginal people of Australia and, indeed, Queensland to wait another 200 years before something is done to return in a secure way a tiny portion of the land which was so brutally and disgracefully stolen from them? He says we do not even know what the Queensland Government intends to do. It is true that no specific proposals have seen the light of day yet. It is also true, if the public brawl in Rockhampton between the Queensland Premier and the President of the National Party is anything to go by, that the form of the proposal is not yet formalised.

But does the Minister and does the Government really expect the leasehold proposal which the Queensland Government is considering to be adequate in granting secure tenure to these people, which I understand is the stated objective of this Government? The Minister asks us to leave it to him to negotiate a settlement with Queensland. All I can say to the House is that, in the absence of any report on the progress or chances of success of the Minister' s approach, one would be mad to accept his soothing platitudes or, indeed, to have any confidence in them. We have seen the way in which he and his predecessors have sold out Aboriginal interests in the past. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) did it in respect of Aurukun and Mornington Island, Senator Chaney did it in respect of Noonkanbah and Senator Baume has done it in respect of the Northern Territory. We have also seen the cruel way in which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has built up the aspirations of the Aboriginal people, has promised them support and has undertaken to atone for the past, but, when the going gets tough, he is nowhere to be seen and nowhere to be found.

This Bill is certainly not premature. The matter is urgent and to pretend otherwise is to be guilty of the grossest deception, ignorance or disinterest. The Minister says it is ill-considered and poorly drafted. The Bill has now been around since 27 August last year-seven months. During that time Senator Ryan in particular has consulted widely on the detail of the Bill. The amendments agreed to by the Senate took account of the views of those whom the Bill will affect if it becomes law. The amendments took account of the reservations of Senator Bonner and Senator Missen and even took account of those drafting shortcomings which Senator Baume identified. He has had plenty of time and opportunities to propose changes to improve the Bill but has chosen not to. His attitude to the detail of the Bill was churlish and, in many cases, simply wrong in fact.

I turn to his last criticism, that Commonwealth intervention is not necessary or, if it is, not yet. That is a fascinating objection. It is not that he rules out Commonwealth intervention; it is just that he does not want it yet, or now. He says that he does not want to upset the delicate negotiations which he is currently having in Queensland. While we notice that the Minister will not let us in on any progress that he might be making in respect of these delicate negotiations, we do not notice the Queensland Premier being too delicate in his constant stream of denunciation of the land rights cause and of any notion of Commonwealth involvement in settling the matter. In any case this Bill, once passed by this House, does not have to be proclaimed immediately. If, as the Minister maintains, great progress is being made, let him have this legislation in his hip pocket as a reminder to the Queensland Government of the alternative if it refuses to give a wholehearted commitment to the question of land rights. Such a prospect might just serve to concentrate what passes for the collective mind of the Queensland Government. The point is that the Bill only becomes effective once it has been proclaimed. That is in the hands of the Government. It has very little time, however, to finalise the legislative progress of such a proposal if it wants to be in a position to act at about the time that the Queensland Government is likely to proceed with its intentions. This Parliament, I understand, is to sit for about another three or four weeks and beyond that period we will be in the winter recess when all opportunities for taking action at this level will evaporate.

We have always said that Commonwealth intervention is a last resort. It will always be better to get the States to provide land rights, just as was stated by the Senate Committee. But we cannot wait for ever and the Aboriginals should not be expected to wait for ever. The Commonwealth should not be allowed to escape the responsibility for what might happen at the Commonwealth Games this year. It knows the strength of feeling amongst Aboriginal people in Queensland. It knows of their determination, reluctant though it is, to let the world know of their plight, if neces- sary by protesting during the period of the Games. It also knows of the potential and even the enthusiasm for brutal responses to these sorts of demonstrations by the Queensland Government and the Queensland police. The Federal Government has, through the vehicle of this Bill and any other devised by it with the same objective, the opportunity to defuse entirely this critical issue. Its failure to act will leave it with the responsibility for whatever happens. If one drop of blood is spilled in the streets of Brisbane in the cause of Aboriginal land rights, the blood will be on the hands of this Prime Minister and his Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. All the considerable goodwill which has been established in Africa and amongst other black countries in recent times will be squandered through a quite shameless lack of political will on the part of this Prime Minister.

I expect that if this Bill is ever debated again in this House the arguments against it from honourable members opposite will range far and wide. I predict that the cop out argument, as I will term it, will be advanced by the Minister for Industrial Relations and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), whom I notice is sitting in the House this evening. They will say, as they have said before, that confrontation is no way to resolve this problem, that it is the innocent Aboriginal people who get caught in the crossfire between the Commonwealth and the Queensland Government and that the matter will descend into at best a litigious argument in the High Court which could take years to resolve . They will say that the State Government will retaliate by denying services such as roads, water, schools, electricity, health and so on to any Aboriginal community for which the Commonwealth seeks to provide land rights against the objections of the Queensland Government.

That may be the regrettable reaction and, of course, in such circumstances the communities involved would be adversely affected. The trouble with that argument is that it assumes that the people of these communities think that things are Christmas the way they are when in fact in many cases it is hard to imagine their being much worse. It also overlooks the fact that this legislation provides that the communities themselves decide whether the provisions would have application for them and they could carefully consider the consequences. In any case this argument is a little meaningless coming from members of a party which prides itself on upholding the sanctity of the law. We will not be stood over by the bunyips from Brisbane who masquerade as a government, and neither should honourable members opposite. To do so is to capitulate again and to deny Aboriginals a chance for dignity and a chance for the future. The prospects of standing up to that govenrnment are best if we do it together. If the Government and the Opposition in this place are of one mind and agreed on this proposal the political fallout, which I expect the Government fears, will be minimal. We offer that agreement and I hope the Government accepts it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. I am pleased to have the opportunity of speaking for only a short time in support of the statements made by my colleague the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) and also in support of the legislation which has come to us from the Senate. This country owes a great debt to Senator Susan Ryan, to the Liberal senators, Senator Bonner and Senator Missen, and to the Australian Democrats in the Senate who supported this Bill when it was carried on the voices. I was interested to read the speech in the Senate by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, in which he said, amongst other things, that this Bill was premature, that when the Queensland legislation is known it will be time to pass judgment. He obviously has not read the statements made by the Premier of Queensland, who indicated that it was proposed that such title as would be given to the reserves on which the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island communities are living would be done under the Lands Act and there would be no need for any legislation. That is still the considered and stated view of the Queensland Government. These reserves, which have existed since the 1890s, have always been authorised under the Lands Act by the government of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been statements by people on the reserves, from officers of Aboriginal councils, expressing their satisfaction with the proposals of the Queensland Government. These people are as concerned as any other person on an Aboriginal reserve about their security of tenure, but it has been put to them that freehold title or any other form of title other than title held in trust would be able to be alienated in the way that lands given to the American Indians in the days of the Theodore Roosevelt Government were sold, with the result that the remnants of those tribes in North America-in the United States of America in particular-are now, once again, dispossessed people. The Queensland Government's attitude to land rights is quite clear. It has never shown any respect for the traditional land rights of Aborigines or Torres Strait Islanders. The first legislation for the protection of Aborigines and the suppression of opium use was brought down in 1893 following a report by Archibald Meston, who became the Protector of Aborigines. These reserves were set up as a means of 'soothing the dying pillow'. Right up to the outbreak of the World War II it was thought that the Aboriginal people were dying out.

Part of that program was the deliberate dispossession of Aboriginals and their removal from where they had traditionally resided to reserves far away. For example, the people from Fraser Island, near Maryborough, were taken to Yarrabah , near Cairns. In my time in the Parliament I have seen people from Beaudesert taken to Palm Island. The exceptions, of course, were those who lived on the isolated reserves of Cape York and the Torres Strait islands. Since the 1890s, Queensland government administrations of all political persuasions have accorded no importance to traditional claims. In more recent times, while certain elements of change have motivated this Government and administrations in the Northern Territory and elsewhere, the Government of Queensland has discouraged traditional ceremonies, movement back to outstations and the like.

The real issue is security of tenure. This is a very modest piece of legislation which purports to give such security to the Aboriginal and Islander people-the sort that applies in respect of the national parks in Queensland. Such land can be alienated only with the consent of Parliament. Although I have mentioned traditional owners, the legislation applies also to Aborigines-for instance some I have met who live at such places as Palm Island-who may not be the traditional occupants of an area but have been there since 1918 or for a considerable period. As we all know, Aborigines have a very close affinity to the place where they were born.

For all of these reasons, because it is right and proper that this Government acknowledge that the land rights principles which it has acknowledged in respect of the Northern Territory should apply also in Queensland, and because of the unfortunate confrontations which may take place during the holding of the Commonwealth Games later this year, this legislation should be supported. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later time.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Howard, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill to amend the income tax law ranges over a number of subjects. Flowing from the 1981-82 Budget, it effects considerable improvements in the zone allowances for people in more isolated areas of Australia, and allows a more rapid write-off of plant for use in the iron and steel industry. In the area of tax-deductible gifts, there are measures to allow deductions for gifts to three Polish relief funds and to certain animal protection societies, as well as some to guard against abuses of the incentives for the arts segment of the gift provisions.

Two groups of amendments of an anti-avoidance nature concern the provisions under which profits from buying and selling property within 12 months are subject to income tax, and the provisions governing the taxing of income derived by trusts. There are also changes of a more technical kind dealing with medical expenses paid to incorporated practices and overseas living-away-from-home allowances of members of the Defence Force.

Important though each of these changes is, the amendment of major significance in the Bill is that concerning international profit shifting arrangements. I foreshadowed this change in my speech to the House on 27 May 1981, when I introduced the legislation that is now in place as Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

I have much pleasure in now bringing into the Parliament the foreshadowed companion amendments, thus completing a package of general measures that are designed to render ineffectual arrangements that have the purpose or effect of avoiding Australian tax. The latest amendments will repeal section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and replace it with revised provisions. The new provisions will deal comprehensively with the shifting of profits out of Australia, whether by transfer pricing or other means.

The measures in the Bill aim to give clear guidance to the Commissioner of Taxation as to the way in which they are applicable. However, the variety of situations that occur in practice is such that the revised provisions, like those they re-express, have had to repose broad powers of judgment in the Commissioner of Taxation. His exercise of these will, of course, be subject to review and appeal in the normal way.

The shifting of profits to minimise or eliminate a taxation liability, while not a new problem, is one that has become increasingly significant in recent years. The growth of international investment, the relative ease with which money, goods and technology cross international boundaries, improved communications, and the development of a network of tax havens have all served to facilitate profit shifting arrangements by transnational enterprises, both Australian and foreign-based. Profit shifting through transfer pricing has also become the subject of considerable public discussion in recent years, both in Australia and abroad.

At the international level, it is appropriate to recognise the valuable work of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development-the OECD-which has formulated guidelines for dealing with transfer pricing in its various forms. Since I announced the Government's intention to revise section 136 to deal more effectively with international profit shifting arrangements, the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, in its report on the development of the bauxite , alumina and aluminium industries, has also commented upon the operation of the existing section and indicated the areas where it considered the section might be strengthened. I am pleased to inform the House that the proposed measures do in fact include provisions along the lines of those which the Committee considered necessary.

Although complementary to Part IVA, the proposed measures are not limited in scope to arrangements that have a dominant tax avoidance purpose. In that regard , it is important to recognise that an arrangement to shift profits out of Australia may be entered into for a complex mixture of tax and other reasons. However, as I mentioned in my earlier statement to the House on this matter, the fact that tax saving is not a key purpose of a particular arrangement or transaction is no reason why we, as a nation, should not be in a position to counteract any loss to the Australian revenue inherent in it.

The main requirements for the application of the revised provisions are that a taxpayer has supplied, or acquired property or services under an 'international agreement', one or more of the parties to which were not dealing at arm's length with each other, and that the supply or acquisition was at prices other than those that might have been expected in a transaction between independent parties dealing independently-that is, at arm's length. The term 'international agreement' is broadly defined but will not affect transactions wholly within Australia where both sides of a transaction are reflected in Australian tax. Where the Commissioner of Taxation determines that the new provisions should apply, arm's length prices will be substituted for income tax purposes in place of those adopted in the profit shifting arrangements.

The revised provisions, like the existing section 136, will permit the scrutiny of profit shifting arrangements-other than those between separate but related entities-that may be made by a single taxpayer who has business operations in more than one country, for example, a taxpayer with a head office in one country and branch operations in another. Profit shifting at this level occurs not through actual purchases or sales, but through book entries involving, for example, the invoicing of goods at non-arm's length prices or the charging to accounts of excessive expenses between head office and a branch. Technically, profit shifting arrangements of this kind involve questions of the source of a taxpayer's income and the extent to which expenditure is incurred in deriving income from a particular source. The Bill therefore contains provisions which authorise the Commissioner of Taxation to determine these questions by reference to arm's length criteria.

An important feature of the new provisions is that, subject to powers of remission, a statutory penalty will be imposed, equal to 10 per cent per annum of the tax becoming payable by virtue of the revised provisions. Without that, taxpayers who engage in profit shifting to reduce their Australian tax liabilities would have the odds to nothing when they engaged in such arrangements. These measures, which are to have effect in relation to income derived and expenditure incurred after 27 May 1981, will overcome a number of deficiencies in the existing section 136. They will, in express terms, bring the Australian income tax law into line with the approach adopted by many other countries and with the provisions already embodied in our double taxation agreements.

Finally, they are, by any standard, a significant legislative response to arrangements that are damaging to the Australian revenue. Before leaving that subject I would like to acknowledge the interest and contribution of a number of members of this House to amendments in this area and not least the contribution of my colleague the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) who has taken a long and consistent interest in this particular subject.
Zone Allowance

Following my Budget announcement I gave details of this change on 15 November 1981. The change follows a careful examination of the zone allowance system in the light of the report of the public inquiry into the system of income tax rebates for people living in more isolated areas.

Under the new arrangements given legal force by the Bill with effect from 1 November 1981, the basic rebates of $216 for zone A and $36 for zone B will not be altered, but the part of the zone rebate that is related to dependants will increase. It will rise from 25 per cent to 50 per cent of the relevant dependant rebate amounts for zone A, and from 4 per cent to 20 per cent for zone B. A special basic rebate of $750, in lieu of the ordinary basic zone A and zone B rebates, will be available for people residing or spending the required period of time, in particularly isolated areas in either zone-that is, at places in excess of 250 kilometres by the shortest practicable surface route from the centre of the nearest population centre of 2,500 people or more; 1976 census data will be used to establish the population of centres for the purpose of the special basic rebate. The situation will be reviewed after 1981 census data becomes available.

Further, the existing test of eligibility for a zone rebate, under which a person must reside or actually be in a zone area for more than half the year of income, will be liberalised in two respects, effective from 1 January 1981. First, a person who resides or spends time in a zone area for 183 days or more over a period of two consecutive income years, but who does not satisfy the existing test in relation to either income year, is to receive a rebate in the later income year. Second, a person who resides in a zone area for a continuous period of up to five income years, but who does not satisfy the existing test in the first and last of those income years, will be entitled to a rebate in the last year, provided the period in the first income year combined with that in the last income year exceeds 182 days.

I mention that to maintain the long-standing relativity between the level of the zone A rebate and that of the rebates available to certain persons serving overseas with a United Nations' armed force and to Defence Force members serving in certain overseas localities, the dependant component of those rebates is also to rise from 25 per cent to 50 per cent.
Depreciation of Basic Iron or Steel Production Plant

Honourable members may recall that details of this Budget measure were announced on 30 October 1981. As announced, special rates of depreciation, on a prime cost basis, are to be provided for new and second hand plant used primarily and principally in the production of basic iron and steel products. The new rate will be 20 per cent except where, under existing law, eligible plant would attract a rate of more than 20 per cent. In those cases, a 33 1/3 per cent rate will apply.

The new measures will apply to eligible plant that is ordered after 18 August 1981 and before 1 July 1991, and is first used or installed ready for use before 1 July 1992. Plant constructed by the taxpayer will qualify on the same basis if construction is started within the 18 August 1981 to 1 July 1991 period.

For the purposes of the special depreciation allowances, basic iron and steel products will be, broadly, those products included in the definition used for the purposes of the 1980 report of the Industries Assistance Commission into the iron and steel industry. In addition, following representations received from the Government of Western Australia, the Government has agreed that sponge iron should also be recognised as a basic iron product for the purposes of the scheme .

As outlined in my 30 October statement the accelerated rates will apply to direct production plant and also to plant used by the producer within the production premises on certain necessary associated processes. Road vehicles of a kind ordinarily used to transport persons or deliver goods will not qualify for the accelerated rates.
Gifts

Amendments proposed by the Bill will further extend the gift provisions of the income tax law. These allow deductions for gifts of the value of $2 or more to specified funds, authorities or institutions. One extension will authorise deductions for gifts made after 5 February 1982 to the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and to the equivalent societies in Queensland and the Northern Territory-the Royal Queensland Society for the Prevention of Cruelty and the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The Acting Treasurer announced this decision on 5 February 1982.

The second will authorise deductions for gifts made to three Polish relief appeals. In a statement on 18 February 1982 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced that gifts made during the current financial year to the Help Poland Live Appeal conducted by the Australian National Committee for Relief to Poland would qualify for deduction. Following representations, the Government has decided that gifts made to the Australian Red Cross Poland Appeal and the World Vision of Australia Poland Emergency Appeal should similarly qualify.

Still further amendments will modify the operation of the taxation incentives for the arts scheme. That scheme authorises deductions under liberalised conditions for gifts of works of art and other cultural property to the Australiana fund, a public art gallery, library, or museum or to Artbank. At present, such gifts qualify for deduction irrespective of the time when, or the manner in which, the gifted property was acquired by the donor. The amount of the deduction available is generally based on the market value of the property at the time the gift was made, determined by reference to the average of two or more valuations obtained from approved valuers.

The first of the modifications proposed to that scheme was foreshadowed in my statement of 14 October 1981. That amendment will, in two specified sets of circumstances, apply to gifts made after that date so as to restrict the amount of the deduction to either the value of the property or any amount paid by the donor for the property, whichever is the lesser. This restriction will apply, firstly, when the property is donated within 12 months of its acquisition by the donor; and, secondly, when the property was acquired by the donor for the purpose of making the donation, or was acquired subject to an agreement or understanding that the property would be so given away. This basis of deduction will not, however, apply to gifts of property inherited by the donor. Such gifts will continue to qualify for the market value basis of deduction. Further amendments cover arrangements for the appointment of valuers under the scheme, by formally placing responsibility for such appointments with the Secretary to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. Guidelines for the purpose are being inserted in the law.
Short-term Property Transactions

I foreshadowed this change in a statement to the House on 10 September 1981. I said then that section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act needs to be amended to support the policy of the section that profits made from short term property transactions are to be subject to income tax. Section 26AAA requires that the assessable income of a taxpayer include any profit arising from the sale of property purchased within the previous 12 months. When a person who owns controlling shares in a company has the company purchase property and, when the property appreciates in value, effectively realises the resulting profit by selling the controlling shares in the interposed company the section does not apply and there is doubt whether the profit is brought to tax by related provisions of the law.

Similar uncertainties could arise in the event of use of a trust as the vehicle for the purchase and sale of assets within 12 months, or by selling off an interest in property held for less than 12 months through a chain of companies, or through interposed companies, partnerships or trusts. The Bill deals with these situations, so that a taxpayer's assessable income will clearly include the profit component of the sale price of shares in a private company or an interest in a trust estate or partnership that is attributable to an increase in the value of underlying property purchased within the preceding 12 months. The amendments will apply when the value of the underlying property immediately before the shares or interest are sold is 75 per cent or more of the net worth of the company, trust estate or partnership.

Section 26AAA is to be further amended so as to apply in a related situation in which a taxpayer sells property received as part of a distribution in specie by a private company or trustee of a trust estate, the property having been purchased within the preceding 12 months. When I announced these measures in the Parliament on 10 September 1981 I indicated that they would apply in relation to underlying property purchased after that date, other than trading stock, depreciable plant or property held for resale at a profit. It has, however, been found necessary to include in the Bill additional safeguarding provisions to prevent taxpayers from being able to exploit a general exclusion of those classes of property. To the extent that these safeguards depart from the terms of my announcement, the further measures will apply only in relation to underlying property that is purchased after today.
Income of Trust Estate and of Dependent Children

I turn now to the amendments that were foreshadowed by me in a statement of 27 August last year. The amendments, which are to operate from that date, are designed to clarify the provisions relating to the system for taxing the income of trust estates and of dependent children that was introduced in 1980 in two areas in which, it has been claimed, loopholes exist. In one case, a blatant tax avoidance scheme was developed in reliance upon the alleged deficiency. The scheme attempts, by the creation of multiple trusts, to exploit the measures adopted in 1980 to free from tax at the maximum personal rate accumulating trust income in respect of which a beneficiary has a vested and indefeasible interest. Under those measures, such income is instead taxed to the trustee on behalf of the beneficiary at personal rates of tax, including the zero rate applying in 1981-82, to the first $4,195 of income. Under the scheme, it has been contended that each of the multiple trusts has a vested and indefeasible interest in, but is not presently entitled to, a share of the net income of the head trust, and that the measure I have just referred to operates to allow each of the multiple trusts to obtain the benefit of the tax-free threshold. I might add that it is not accepted that the scheme is effective, but these amendments will modify the relevant provisions of the law so that such unintended results clearly do not occur.

The other amendment under this head relates to the exemption from the special tax applicable to the income of minors, for income derived by a minor from his or her employment. It has been claimed that, because the definition of employment income adopted in the law includes payments made for services rendered, the exemption extends to income that a child receives from a trust estate that derives that income from carrying on a business of providing services performed by its employees. This claim is contrary to the intention of the law and the amendment will indicate expressly that the exemption from the special tax in respect of employment income that a child beneficiary receives through a trust is applicable only when the beneficiary provides the services. A related amendment, to apply after today, will clarify the scope of and the application of safeguards in relation to the exemption for business income derived by a child from carrying on a business, either alone or in partnership with others, to make it clear that business income includes income from a business of providing services.
Medical Expenses

At present medical expenses paid to a qualified person are eligible for the general income tax rebate. The law is to be amended so that medical expenses of the kinds that qualify under the existing provisions will also be rebatable when paid in respect of a professional service provided by a qualified person although the payment itself is made to a corporate or other unqualified employer of that person. The amendment will apply to payments made on or after 1 July 1981 and is in recognition of relaxed rules of professional bodies in permiting the incorporation of medical and other professional practices.
Living-away-from-home Allowances

Finally, a technical change in the law will remove the present exclusion of members of the Defence Force from the operation of the provision which authorises a deduction against the amount of any living away from home allowance that is required to be included in the assessable income of an employee. The amendment will ensure that allowances in the nature of living away from home allowances received by Defence Force personnel serving overseas continue to be taxed to the same extent as similar allowances received by their civilian counterparts. All of these measures are explained in some detail in the explanatory memorandum that is being made available to honourable members. In those circumstances, I need do no more at this stage than commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Dawkins) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hunt, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend Part IV of the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act to accord with the Government's decision to increase the liability limits applying to domestic and non-Convention international air carriage and to make provision for the Act to cover the new air service licence classifications that are to be introduced. The Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act gives force of law in Australia to the Warsaw Convention and the Hague Protocol which limit the extent of airlines' liabilities in respect of damages arising from carriage on international flights. More specifically, Part IV of the Act applies similar conditions to domestic airline and charter operations in Australia and to non-Convention international carriage. Under Part IV of the Act the liability of domestic and non-Convention international carriers for death or injury to passengers, or damage to baggage, is limited. Passengers, or their relatives, do not need to prove negligence on the part of the operator. The injured party is required to prove the amount of damages being claimed and the amount awarded is then limited by the Act.

The Government has been concerned particularly at the adequacy of domestic liability levels which were last reviewed in 1976. The 1976 amendments reflected the levels that generally applied to international operations. However, the liability limits provided by the Warsaw Convention and associated instruments are expressed in terms of gold francs, the value of which has fluctuated considerably in recent years with movements in the price of gold. To rectify this situation, an international conference in Montreal in 1975 sought to introduce new protocols which express the limits in International Monetary Fund special drawing rights. However, these protocols have yet to come into force and the Government is currently examining possible interim arrangements regarding limits on airline liability for international carriage until such time as the protocols take effect. The Government is also concerned with the broader question of compulsory insurance for the domestic carriers' liability to passengers. This matter is presently under consideration in joint Commonwealth- State government forums. The question of an even broader third party compulsory insurance scheme is also of concern and is, however, a much more complex issue for which consideration will be required by both the Commonwealth and the States . Undoubtedly they are issues that need urgent action.

I now turn to the specific provisions of the Bill. Clause 2 of the Bill makes provision for the Act to commence operation on a date to be proclamed. In order that the operators may be given sufficient notice to effect any necessary insurance arrangements the proclamation date will be a short while after the Bill's passage through the Parliament. Provision also exists to make a separate proclamation for clause 3 to coincide with the commencement of new air service licensing arrangements. Later this year, it is proposed to introduce regulations under the Air Navigation Act to provide for new air service licence categories. In particular, commuter and cargo operators will receive clear acknowledgment of their increasingly important role in the provision of aviation services by introducing new licence categories-the supplementary airline licence and licences for cargo-only operators.

Clause 3 extends the definitions of 'airline licence' and 'charter license' in section 26 of the principal Act so that carriage by operators under the proposed new air service licence classifications will continue to be covered by the provisions of the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act. Clause 4 of the Bill amends Part IV of the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959 to increase the level of liability for death or injury to passengers from $45,000 to $100, 000. Similar increases apply for the liability limits for damage to baggage. For registered baggage the limit will be increased from $300 to $900. For baggage in the passengers' own care, the increase will be from $30 to $90. Provision is also made for these limits to be amended by regulation in future. This will facilitate introduction of what are essentially machinery amendments and allow a more regular review of the liability limits that apply. The Bill also makes provisions for the existing liability limits to continue to apply to all accidents that may have taken place before the date of commencement of the increased liability provisions. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AIR ACCIDENTS (COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT LIABILITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hunt, and read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill complements the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill 1982 which I have just introduced into the House. The Air Accidents ( Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963 is a companion statute to the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959. It applies to persons travelling as passengers in aircraft operated by the Commonwealth and to passengers on aircraft not so operated who are travelling as Commonwealth employees, or other persons whose cost of travel is met by the Commonwealth or who are travelling for the purposes of the Commonwealth. This Bill increases from $45,000 to $100, 000 the limit of liability of the Commonwealth in respect of personal injury or death arising from an air accident. This is consistent with the limits proposed in the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill 1982 which I have just introduced. By this Bill, the Commonwealth will meet the same conditions of liability in respect of air accidents as it imposes on commercial airlines and charter operators.

The Bill also extends the application of the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963 to certain classes of persons currently without a cause of action under the legislation. The definition of 'passenger' has been broadened to cover aircrew and airborne workers, such as aerial photographers, instrument fitters, et cetera. This extension of coverage is based on the Government's view that there is normally a commonality of employment between aircrew, airborne workers and passengers carried in aircraft on Commonwealth sponsored flights to which the legislation applies. Under the new criteria all Commonwealth employees killed or injured in aircraft accidents on such flights will have a similar cause of action against the Commonwealth for damages. The provision does not, however, apply to aircrew of an authority or corporation undertaking commercial transport operations. The Bill also contains a provision whereby persons with concurrent repatriation pension rights arising from an air accident during peacetime service will no longer be debarred from claiming damages under the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963. In 1973, repatriation entitlement was extended to cover peacetime defence service and the exclusion provision of the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963 thereupon debarred a cause of action against the Commonwealth for damages. The modification of the exclusion provisions now proposed will mean that, where concurrent entitlement to a repatriation pension arises during peacetime service, a member of the Defence Force or his dependants will now also have a cause of action under the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963. Any damages awarded as the result of a claim will be taken into account to reduce the concurrent repatriation pension so as to avoid any 'double benefit' accruing in respect of the one accident. Finally, liability under the principal Act is proposed to be adjusted in future by reference to the limit of liability applicable under section 31 (1) of the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959 as proposed to be amended by the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill 1982. I commend the Bill to the House.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Act in a number of respects. The main amendments proposed by the Bill deal with the levels of penalty for customs offences. Other amendments are directed at controls over the unloading and handling of cargo, the licensing of depots for short term holding of goods, the entering of goods and duty exemptions on ships' and aircraft's stores. The report of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs pointed out inadequacies in the penalties for breaches of the Customs Act. Other inadequacies in Customs Act penalties were highlighted last year in the context of offences committed in the unlawful exportation of horse and kangaroo meat to the United States. As part of the Government's response to those issues, a general review of Customs Act penalties has been undertaken in consultation with the Government's legal advisers.

The review took into consideration the matters to which I have just referred, the difficulties faced by Customs in supervising the growing flow of goods into and out of Australia, the need for Customs to rely to a significant degree on the integrity of importers and exporters and the magnitude of the rewards that can be obtained from revenue evasion or unlawful import or export activities. It was concluded that the levels of penalties for most non-narcotics Customs offences should be substantially increased. The Bill proposes that the penalty for revenue-related offences should be up to five times the amount sought to be evaded and not less than two times that amount. For the offences of importing prohibited imports or exporting prohibited exports a maximum penalty equivalent to three times the value of the goods is proposed. Where the amount evaded or the value of the goods cannot be ascertained, it is proposed that a maximum penalty of $50,000 should apply. It is further proposed that this maximum of $50 ,000 should also be the prescribed penalty for other offences which strike at the very basis of Customs control. Included in this category are offences such as failure by the master of a ship to permit his ship to be boarded or the pilot of an aircraft to land for boarding, the bringing of a ship or aircraft to an unauthorised place and the unlawful interference with containers or goods between the time of landing and their clearance by Customs.

In respect of some offences which, while serious, are not amongst the most important, a maximum penalty of $25,000 is proposed. Examples of such offences are the unloading without permission of imported cargo or cargo that has been loaded for export. A maximum penalty of $10,000 is proposed for offences such as failing to comply with conditions to which permission for the importation, exportation or movement of goods is subject and for other offences of equal seriousness. Other proposed maximum penalties range from $5,000 for offences such as interfering with customs seals, through $2,000 for offences such as failure to deliver up imported goods that have been washed ashore or salvaged, to $1,000 for offences such as failure to furnish export returns and failure by licensees of warehouses and owners of warehoused goods to observe certain requirements in relation to facilities and documentation.

No action is proposed by this Bill in relation to penalties for narcotics offences punishable under section 235 of the Customs Act. Those penalties were reviewed and substantially increased by amendments in 1977 and 1979. The penalties already provided under section 235 range from $2,000 or two years, or both, for simple possession of imported narcotics up to a penalty of $100,000 or 25 years, or both, for trafficking in narcotics. There is further provision for imposing a penalty of life imprisonment in the most serious cases.

With the penalty increases, consequential adjustments have become necessary to ensure that customs prosecutions may be brought in an appropriate court. At present the Act provides that prosecutions involving a pecuniary penalty not exceeding $1,000 may be instituted in courts of summary jurisdiction and in intermediate courts. In order to allow the increased penalties to be recovered without having to institute comparatively minor prosecutions at the Supreme Court level, greater use is to be made of the existing intermediate level of courts. The jurisdictional level of intermediate courts is to be increased to $ 20,000. Other amendments increase the jurisdictional level of courts of summary jurisdiction to $5,000. Other amendments will extend the present system of dealing administratively with relatively minor offences committed by arriving international passengers or crew. These provisions will now apply also to offences committed by other persons which could lead to forfeiture of goods and where the duty evaded is $500 or less.

The Bill also proposes amendments to provisions governing the lodgment and processing of entries of goods for home consumption. The changes simplify, update and remedy defects in existing provisions to clarify these requirements on importers. The principal change involves fixing the effective date of entry to establish a duty rate for entries lodged with a Collector prior to the arrival of the goods at their intended discharge port or airport. Presently, advance entries are not effective until the goods actually arrive at that port or airport. This requirement has given rise to anomalous situations where identical goods may attract different rates of duty depending on the time of arrival of the carrying ship at various Australian ports. Delays in a ship's movements around Australia may also prevent some of a shipment of identical goods on the same vessel which are discharged at different ports, being entered in time to meet deadlines applying under import quota arrangements. The Bill proposes amendments which will make the effective entry date the date on which the carrying ship or aircraft arrives at its first port or airport in Australia. Other amendments are proposed which will clarify administrative aspects of the lodgment and withdrawal of entries.

A further important amendment is the proposed creation of a Part VA to introduce a new system of licensing for places used as depots for holding imported goods and goods for export prior to their examination by Customs. In view of the similarity of operation of premises used for the long term warehousing of goods subject to Customs control and the short term holding of goods for examination in depots, the licensing scheme proposed in the Bill is modelled directly on that now applying in respect of warehouses. The proposed new depot licensing provisions set out criteria under which licences may be granted, provide authority for the imposition of conditions, the charging of fees and certain disciplinary powers in the event of a breach of the terms of a licence.

The Bill also proposes amendment of provisions of the Act dealing with the report, unshipment, placement and movement of imported cargo. These proposals will correct deficiencies in the existing provisions which fail to accommodate modern cargo handling procedures, particularly in relation to containerised cargo. Minor changes are proposed to be made to provisions covering the licensing of Customs warehouses and Customs agents. These will overcome administrative difficulties in the operation of these schemes. Finally, the Bill proposes amendments to clarify the exemptions applicable to stores for use in ships and aircraft.

These amendments are proposed to be made to both the Customs Act and the Excise Act. They are designed to ensure that the exemption applies only in respect of ships and aircraft while they are actually engaged on international voyages or flights. It is intended that, after the second reading is agreed to, this will be referred to the Legislation Committee of this House.
I commend the Bill to the House.
