Yet the New South Wales Minister for Mines and Energy approved a $ 63 a week increase in the basic award which was, I understand, the top bid of the combined mining unions and not the bid that they would happily have accepted . The companies will have to find about $120 per week to cover that $63 per week award increase, allowing for overtime, shift allowances, penalty rates, et cetera. That is the equivalent of about $4 per tonne of coal. I understand that even trainee typists receive nearly $20,000 per year, including bonuses, within the industry. We know that those in the higher echelons of the industry, such as deputies, are in the bracket of $50,000 to $55,000 a year.

The next major problem that the industry has-perhaps the greatest problems by far-is that of industrial relations. We have the most unfortunate situation in which some of our major customers, such as Japan, are saying that they are no longer interested in dealing with us, to the same extent at least, because of cost pressures, particularly wages, and because of the instability, unpredictability and unreliability of Australia as a coal supplier. Japan has indicated that it would like to take about 11 million tonnes less this year from New South Wales. That will go in small part to Queensland but mostly it will go to overseas suppliers, such as the United States of America and South Africa. South Africa is doubling its export effort. The United States, despite the fact that it has lower quality coal and has to transport it some 1,500 kilometres, has set up a presidential task force to facilitate in any way possible the export of coal from that country, obviously to take advantage of our uncompetitive situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you like South Africa's industrial relations?

—The honourable member for Wills might be interested in this: The reduction for New South Wales of 11 million tonnes can be directly reflected in a loss of 5,500 jobs, plus prospective jobs and the multiplier effect that I talked about earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to port delays. Perhaps members of the Opposition are interested in the fact that it is not uncommon for carriers to wait four months off Port Kembla or Newcastle for orders to be filled. One company that I know of has had to wait five months to fill a ship and the demurrage charges on that were so high that the total of them exceeded the value of the cargo. Demurrage charges are crippling the industry. We have the ridiculous spectre of some 50 to 60 ships- Wran's navy, as it has been coined-sitting off Newcastle and Port Kembla. There will be virtually no shipping in April of this year. Perhaps it would be of interest to members of the Opposition to realise that New South Wales increased its exports by 300,000 tonnes last year; that is, by 1.3 per cent, as opposed to Queensland, which increased its exports by 39 per cent. That reduction in exports was almost entirely due to shipping delays.

On another aspect of industrial relations, I learned recently that there are some 24 unions between the coal face and the bulk carrier. For perhaps the first time in the industry's history, the combined mining unions have met with the waterfront unions because they have started to realise that they are sowing the seeds of their own destruction. They have told their boys in the Hunter Valley to go slow because they realise that there are huge stockpiles. Of course, this really does not help because it increases the unit cost of the extraction of coal. I mention that a stockpile of 12 million tonnes, nearly half of what New South Wales exported last year, is now sitting on the grass waiting to be shipped. If we translate that into interest that has to be borne by the industry we come up with a figure of about $100m or $4 per tonne of coal.

I turn now to another difficulty that besets the industry; that is, the effect of Government charges. There is a multitude of visible and hidden charges, both by State governments and the Commonwealth Government, which do not help the situation at the moment. I believe the most significant charges originate within the States. Notwithstanding that, it is interesting to note that in the last seven years there have been some 33 taxation decisions-not all disadvantageous, of course-that have affected the industry. That creates a very great problem for the industry so far as the instability and unpredictability of its operating conditions are concerned. In New South Wales, 60 per cent of the industry's operating profits have to go in government charges, royalties or levies of some sort. Let us look at the New South Wales charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —New South Wales charges? What about Queensland charges?

—I was waiting for the interjection from the honourable member for Cunningham. Would he be interested to know that the average annual increase in rail freight in New South Wales over the last five years has been 13 per cent? There was an increase of 10 1/2 per cent in April 1980, 17 per cent in January 1981 and 25 per cent this year. That is a total of 52 1/2 per cent in two years. If we take it over three years, it is 80 per cent. For his information by comparison, Queensland's freight costs on a tonne per kilometre basis are 60 per cent of those of New South Wales. Yet in New South Wales the industry is compelled to use the railways. Furthermore, the industry is required to provide much of its rail infrastructure, whether it be rail lines or wagons. At the moment the industry has to find $75m in order to provide 700 rail wagons. By 1990 it will have to provide another 2,300 rail wagons. In New South Wales royalties have increased 70 per cent in this last year, an increase of 800 per cent over the last 10 years. Power charges went up 25 per cent at the end of last year. Goodness knows what they will be this year. Yet the industry has to provide its own infrastructure to get its power supply from the Electricity Commission of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the question of port charges. The industry, despite the fact that it has witnessed no increase in throughput at ports was last year hit by the New South Wales Government with a 47 per cent increase in port charges. Demurrage, which I have already mentioned, is running at between $10,000 and $13,000 a day, or between $5 a tonne and $6 a tonne. We see now a devastatingly worrying situation in which organisations that provide insurance cover against strikes are no longer keen to cover operations in Australia. That will hit the industry even harder. I learnt recently that one company had to pay out $1m in demurrage alone.

Let us consider also the question of front-end payments, which are the name of the game in the various States, with Queensland being just as bad in this respect as New South Wales. As part of the conditions of tendering for a lease, companies have been expected to provide up-front money amounting to between $10m and $20m. The local councils have got into the act and are requiring up-front money for infrastructure. Of course, the cost of that infrastructure is not deductible as a capital outlay, a matter that the Commonwealth Government could well consider.

I wish to refer now to Commonwealth charges. The export levy of $1 a tonne on steaming coal is a discriminatory charge which has no relativity to profit. I am of the view that the Commonwealth could well consider seriously reducing or abolishing that charge, provided the States were prepared to do likewise. I refer again to the requirement that the industry has to provide its own infrastructure, for example in connection with the provision of electricity connections and rail wagons.

Of course, in recent times, with the oil crisis, steaming coal in particular has had an opportunity to really take off. It had the opportunity-indeed it may still have if we can rectify some of these problems-of increasing its present export capacity of 50 million tonnes to some 200 million tonnes in the 1990s. What a dramatic opportunity exists for unionists, governments, the industry and indeed the Australian people to take advantage of. Even now some five million of the 18 1/2 million barrels of oil produced in the world each day are going into furnaces. The opportunity can still be taken to make the coal industry the black gold boom industry of Australia, but that can be achieved only if there is common sense amongst governments and unions, so that we can persuade our customers that we can be a reliable and predictable supplier.

Growth in the industry has not yet taken off. The figure of 6.5 per cent per annum is about the same as it was, in real terms, in the 1950s. The industry is facing market difficulties. We are seeing other countries look elsewhere because of our unpredictability and unreliability. We have an opportunity to hold onto these markets and expand them if governments play the ball the right way and, likewise, unionists realise that strikes and excessive pay demands not only will jeopardise their jobs but may well hand our coal markets over to other countries , as buyers look for more reliable suppliers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak tonight on an issue which I have raised a number of times in the adjournment debate, and that is the future of Canberra's economic growth and the need for an end to the stop-start growth of Canberra. I want to take this opportunity to read from sections of that annual report. I hope that the Government members who are listening, particularly the Treasurer (Mr Howard), who is in the chamber tonight, will take note of the recommendations of the Canberra Chamber of Commerce. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Canberra's economy is highly sensitive to even slight changes in Commonwealth Government policies, particularly those affecting staff and public works programmes.
The report states that this has:
had the effect of reducing scheduled gross Commonwealth economic inputs to Canberra and at the same time undermining private investment confidence.
It points out that there has been a decline in Canberra's private sector employment. It states the figures and points out that private sector employment:
has declined each year at an average rate of 3 per cent or by about 1000 per annum.

The report continues:

However the one ingredient which the Commonwealth seems to be incapable of supplying is a measure of consistency in its economic inputs. The economic tap has been turned on and off with increasing frequency to suit the Commonwealth's own particular needs, but with scant regard for the impact of such adjustments on the growth and development of Canberra's business sector.

The Chamber does not suggest that the Commonwealth should spend money on Canberra simply to prop up local businesses but rather that it should examine its self-interest and adopt a new business-like, returns-oriented approach to the management of its existing massive investment in Canberra's infrastructure, and that it manage its economic inputs and adjustments in such a way as to provide a far greater measure of consistency and stability than has hitherto been the case.
The report further states:

Given this sort of setting there is no question that Canberra's private sector could grow, diversify and prosper and begin to create the new jobs so desperately required by our growing numbers of school leavers.

The point that is highlighted throughout this report is that what Canberra needs is a commitment from the Federal Government to Canberra's growth and a plan so that the business community knows where it is going. The report also points out the effects that the Review of Commonwealth Functions has had on the Australian Capital Territory. It states:
The combined effect of these particular decisions will be to slow Canberra's growth.

The Chamber apparently met the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch), who is the head of the review committee, and stressed the need for more sensitive management of Canberra's economy. I thank the members of the Chamber of Commerce in the Australian Capital Territory for giving such a frank account of the problems of the business sector in this community and I hope that their recommendations are taken heed of by the members of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would be no question in this House as to the contribution made by the Australian agricultural industry to the Australian economy. This industry suffers many threats, not the least of which is pestilence and disease. Tonight I draw the attention of the House to a threat which materialised in Western Australia in 1968 and which could threaten the viability of one of Australia's top pasture grasses. I refer to rye grass and a resultant stock toxin which has become known as annual rye grass toxicity, ARGT. Rye grass toxicity occurs when, for reasons I will shortly describe, the otherwise beneficial rye grass produces a deadly toxic gall. The occurrence is annual and matches the maturing of the rye grass seed. Rye grass is a vigorous and productive grass pasture ideally suited to Australian soil and dry land conditions. There is no known equivalent replacement for its specialist values. I am unable to say accurately what percentage of Australia's grazier farmers rely on this grass, but I can assure honourable members that it is very high.

SPEECH.PARA: Like most other plants, rye grass is a host to a nematode, angina agrostos. This nematode, whilst affecting production to some degree, is otherwise harmless . However, in areas affected by ARGT the nematode is host to a bacterium, of the corynebacteriaceae species. This bacterium accompanies the nematode when, to complete its life cycle, the nematode enters the rye grass seed head. In most cases the nematode then purely converts the seed to a useless gall which houses its eggs. However, on some occasions the bacterium achieves ascendancy and kills the nematode. The bacterium then reacts with the seed, producing a highly toxic gall.

When these galls are eaten by livestock, the toxins so generated act upon the central nervous system and liver of the animal. Death, preceded by a lengthy period of semi-paralysis and convulsion, is the result. To have observed this phenomenon, especially in larger animals such as mature cattle, is alarming, to say the least. Might I comment at this time, Mr Deputy Speaker, that such an exercise should be recommended to the average suburban animal libber, so that they might get into better order their priorities for expending their time and money in supporting dumb animals?

The stock can be saved only if removed from the affected padocks after a very small intake of galls. Although certain warning signs are obvious, both on the plants and in the behaviour of affected stock, the time span to react to these indicators is short and they are easily missed in broad acre farming activities. A sheep flock worth many thousands of dollars can be wiped out overnight. Various remedies are promoted but the only sure-fire action is to burn completely the affected paddock. The ARGT normally surfaces between October and December and in the areas concerned this means no pasture regeneration until the following winter.

The disease is still confined to my electorate and was first identified in 1968 in a very limited area. It has now been identified on 270 properties. These range north to south over 450 kilometres and east and west up to 100 kilometres. The spread is increasing at 20 per cent per annum. It was also identified in South Australia in the 1950s and has recently surfaced in South Africa. Recorded stock losses are low, 21,000. This figure would in reality be a fraction of total losses. Further, no measure can be made of those who have been forced to abandon livestock production completely.

The Western Australian Department of Agriculture, through the Western Australian Animal Health Laboratories and in conjunction with the Department's South Australian counterpart, has waged a lone war against this problem. Expenditure on research in Western Australia over the last five years has totalled $2m, all but $0.5m being donated by industry groups such as the Australian Wool Corporation and the Australian Meat Research Committee. The rest has been provided by the Western Australian Government. Dr Allen Purcell has led this program for some time. Results to date have included isolation of the toxins, which was an important and difficult step. A dedicated researcher, Dr Paul Vogel, is now working to develop a vaccine, this being a difficult but practical direction. However, early success can be achieved only by expanded effort. Expanded effort means expanded expenditure.

When one considers the rapid spread of ARGT in Western Australia there is little doubt that it could condemn all areas of Australian agriculture where rye grass is the principal pasture, with resulting huge losses or disaster when the pendulum swings back from grain production to grazing. This problem is already national. It transcends State borders. Funding cannot remain the responsibility of the States. National funding is imperative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond very briefly to some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) on the subject of interest rates. Let me say at the outset that I can understand the concern the honourable member expressed on behalf of his constituents about the current level of interest rates. Nobody finds the present level of interest rates to be comfortable. Nobody wishes that they remain at the present level. The question is whether any- thing can responsibly be done to bring down those interest rates for any lasting period and whether in fact there is any realistic alternative to the present interest rate regime that does not involve other than a very short term reduction in interest rates at the cost of much higher inflation and still higher interest rates in the medium to longer term.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member referred to the impact on private interest rate levels of the borrowings of government and semi-government authorities. I must say that I endorse every single remark that the honourable member made in this regard. The Government and I have been arguing for some time now that the overall borrowing requirements of governments have driven up private sector interest rates in this country. I can only urge the honourable member to use his undoubted influence and good offices on the Queensland Government to curb the borrowing proclivities of that Government and its various authorities.

The honourable member also mentioned the impact on interest rates of the huge Australian Wheat Board borrowing of almost $2,000m this year. That has had a marked impact. He will be aware that a couple of years ago, in lieu of the first advance being paid out of the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank, the Government decided for monetary policy reasons that that money should be borrowed commercially. I would have to say to the honourable member that if in fact all of that had been advanced out of the Rural Credits Department the addition of that amount of money to the money supply would indeed have been quite considerable.

He mentioned the possibility of releases from the statutory reserve deposits of the trading banks held by the Reserve Bank. This, of course, is a general monetary policy instrument and it is available for general liquidity purposes. It would be one of the things that the Reserve Bank could do over the coming months if it felt that some easing of liquidity was desirable. I would caution very strongly against believing that specific SRD releases are a solution to the problems of interest rates in particular areas. The purpose of the statutory reserve deposits is to influence the general level of liquidity and not the specific interest rate level in a particular sector of the economy.

To put it another way, if there were a special SRD release for a particular sector and if, in a few months, it became necessary for general tightening of liquidity purposes to make an SRD call, where would that call fall? Would it fall on the sector which had received the last release or would it be distributed throughout the entire banking system? What would be the distributional consequences? Would the sector that did not receive it in the first place have to bear a disproportionate burden of the call? That really illustrates, in my view, that, however superficially attractive, the idea of specific SRD releases raises a large number of impracticalities.

The honourable member also mentioned the question of increasing the interest rates on statutory reserve deposits. This is one of the matters that I mentioned in my statement last week had been discussed between the banks and the Government in the context of other matters that were mentioned in that statement . It is, of course, something that is within the initiative of the Reserve Bank. I simply say again to the honourable member that the possibility of paying an increased interest rate on statutory reserve deposits would arise in the context that, in the event of lending guides being removed as a monetary policy instrument, in all probability the SRD device would be used more frequently as a monetary policy instrument and that as a consequence it would not be unreasonable for there to be an increased rate of interest on the SRDs. The report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System recommended that those deposits bear a market rate. What we are contemplating is only about 5 per cent.

Several overseas studies which have reported increased incidences of morbidity are under question because of poor control techniques employed in the social surveying procedures. Other studies have reported no direct evidence of an association between aircraft noise and health.
(3) Not applicable.

(4) A significant amount of published research has been carried out throughout the world on the subject of the effect of noise, including aircraft noise, on man, and this is continuing. There are considerable practical problems in relation to methodology in the study of the effect of noise on health which are virtually impossible to control. Because of this, commissioning a study within Australia on the matter is not considered to be warranted at this time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether the Prime Minister assured the Australian public in 1977 that no uranium contracts would be drawn up with a customer country until that country had signed a safeguards agreement.
(2) Can such contracts now be signed without a safeguards agreement; if so, why .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Prime Minister announced on 24 May 1977 that Australia would require the prior conclusion of bilateral agreements between the Australian Government and countries wishing to import Australian uranium.

(2) I refer the honourable member to a statement (issued as a media release) which I made on 1 February 1979 in which I announced that companies which have received Commonwealth approval to develop uranium deposits will be allowed to negotiate sales contracts with prospective customers which provide that delivery is conditional on safeguards agreements entering into force.
Companies will thus be able to enter into contracts to secure markets in order to help finance development.

The policy is quite clear: no customer will be able to import Australian uranium before safeguards agreements have been concluded. This is completely consistent with the Government's safeguards policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Bureau of Transport Economics released a Report entitled 'Demand for Sea Passenger Transport Between Tasmania and the Australian Mainland' in August 1980 .
